Author: michwill#0866
Content: Well, acting in self-interested way is bound to find an equilibrium eventually

Author: michwill#0866
Content: It incentivizes everyone to have a skin in the game and be interested in this governance mechanism

Author: michwill#0866
Content: In addition

Author: michwill#0866
Content: Imagine a Balancer-like system but without manual whitelisting

Author: michwill#0866
Content: Say you have tokens A/B

Author: michwill#0866
Content: You wrap them as [A/B] in a pool, put in another pool [[A/B], A]

Author: michwill#0866
Content: Take that, put in another pool

Author: michwill#0866
Content: By putting pools one in another, you could theoretically earn infinite rewards with the same funds

Author: michwill#0866
Content: So one has to penalize that behavior manually

Author: michwill#0866

That's actually not true. Imagine you provide 1% of voting power (and the SuperWhale having 99%), to bootstrap a new pool. If pool has 0.001% funds in it, it has 100x returns vs other pools, so it quickly grows to around 1% of TVL

Author: c2tp
Content:
> So arguably, liquidity distribution is more decentralized than before

like i see the point from both sides so its hard to say for me.   but for example the shift of susd, y, comp is an easy shift because its the same asset class basically.  when curve has usd/usd. btc/btc, eth,eth, euro/euro, gold/gold  it still seems like theyll get pushed out .
So if someone can throw in 1% of voting rights to say give the gold pool a boost,  the initial returns will be good since no one is in the pool but the max liquidity still hits a limiting factor up to 1%.

but then you could say well all those new people in the pool could vote to expand it etc.   and maybe that works out?  this is why im still in on the fence just cause I cant discern that it will because old voting power doesnt go away and should always be able to keep 99% of votes in their favor.

Author: domob
Content: @Deleted User Ok I see, but that may still be income depending on the jurisdiction.  In Switzerland, it would be.  Investment funds that reinvest dividends (and thus do exactly the same thing) still apply for income tax, even if the pure capital gains (without dividends) would be free.  I assume also the free capital gains in Germany and Austria on crypto wouldn't apply there.  (Although of coruse I'm not a lawyer or tax advisor.)

Author: reinis_frp
Content: If you establish limited liability company in Latvia, then all reinvested profit is corporate income tax free. sure, you have to prove real economic activity in Latvia, pay salary+taxes for your farming work and have some admin expenses (e.g. accounting, office, etc.), but all the remaining profit is taxed only when you pay it out to yourself as dividend. sure, due to admin costs it is efficient starting from some minimum income (e.g. $5k/month)

Author: anthonygossage
Content: Something to consider: Only allow proposal voting to occur if a sufficient number of unique addresses have vote locked their CRV. This way, you ensure a certain degree of decentralization before proposals can be passed. You would probably need to have some sort of filter that doesn't count addresses that aren't the original LP addresses to avoid someone from spreading their CRV over multiple addresses in order to get over the unique locker threshold.

Author: dripdrop#3124
Content:
https://discordapp.com/channels/729808684359876718/729808685009731610/747275450287652875  Thoughts? Currently it seems the boost gauges incentivizes users to put more liquidity in the biggest pools. Should we consider to reverse it and incentivize putting liquidity in the smallest pools? (Basically, taking the inverse of the weighting equation... so smallest pools have the biggest allocation of rewards and biggest pools have the smallest allocation of rewards per dollar staked...)

Not only do smaller pools have the smaller rewards (due to the gauge voting allocation), but they also have the most "expensive" boost. You'd have to lock up a lot more CRV to unlock a 2.5x boost in a small pool. This is a double disincentive to provide liquidity to smaller pools.

Author: jiecut#9734
Content: @dripdrop It makes sense that it's harder to get a full boost in a smaller pool. People could always vote in the guage weight vote, to increase weight for smaller pools.

Author: jiecut#9734
Content: It's proportional. It sort of encourages you to be balanced by the weight chosen.

Author: dripdrop#3124
Content: But they won't. Both whales in big pools and popular average small users in big pools will usually vote to keep rewards for their current pool.

Author: jiecut#9734
Content: We don't know how the guage weight votes will work, only 1 week so far.

Author: dripdrop#3124
Content: Look how quickly the COMP advantage went away. The small pools will be too small to make it worthwhile for big whales maybe too? I dunno. I'm just guessing based on the new calculator https://dao.curve.fi/minter/calc  But yeah, I guess we'll see what happens over time. This is just my current hunch.

Author: jiecut#9734
Content: @dripdrop Oh, I think it's expected for APR to normalize across pools. But if you think a pool is too small, you can vote for it to get a higher weighting.

Author: anthonygossage
Content: gauge weights were a bad idea when combined with the way boost works. All the incentives are to put your money into the biggest pool and vote to gauge weight that pool with your locked veCRV since bigger pools lead to higher boost. I'd rather keep my deposit in s pool, but it will take ~5x more veCRV to reach max boost than in y pool. Without the gauge weights, the smaller rewards from the larger pool would offset the easier boost it provides, making for a more balanced incentive system.

Content:
> Can we have in a lock in period for every unvesting token or daily yielding token inflation via the dao? Is it possible? Since handing over the token immediately only harms the ecosystems with both vested/newly minted from current lp's system?

@Doomlordxxx 
think this just delays the release point of the tokens. so say newly minted coins from farming get a 1 month lock, that just moves the inflation rate forward 1 month.  so in 1 month you're right back to where you were.

handing over the token isnt a bad thing.  its a reward and should be used as such. "harming the ecosystem" sounds like a scared of farmers selling sort of thing.  if they dont want to hold they should be able to sell.  if you want more people to hold, all we need to do is give value to the coin.
basically you have two choices:  sell crv and reinvest the profits so that you can farm more faster,  hold on to crv because you think it will be good later.
both are fair points and neither is bad.
as soon as tokens are used to say, receive fees from the system, the value of a crv token will instantly be realized and the ecosystem will come to a full cycle.   right now holding is just speculative.

thus locking etc and making it harder for people to use the rewards they properly earn doesnt really help with anything in my opinion

Author: Doomlordxxx#8027
Content:
But at the immediate juncture with a hyperinflative release, you cannot create that much value. And value is related to demand. And demand is related to supply. Where already demand is created for boost governance and related activities you can simply make it more valuable by reducing the "instantly available supply" by delaying you make them longer interested. And also calling it "properly earned" is not exactly right according to me, didn't vitalik himself say what APY'S higher than financial systems mean.
To realise this apy at the expected rates they will indirectly harm the ecosystem. And the balance between "properly earned rewards" and not causing "undue imbalanced harm " needs more weight and tighter according to me :)

Author: traderex1
Content:
Free market and voluntariness is most important to achieve real/fair pricing. Locking / boosting is a cool thing, just changes the timeline of price dynamics, its a cool game.

Rewarding liquidity providers is the reason why Curve is where they are, people who buy the token to speculate do so at their own risk.

One extreme is to lock everybody's LP rewards for 100years, price goes to 100 trillion, it will be monopoly money.

Best model is always free market with uncertain games and stuff like lock/vote/boost stuff to find real valuation. If Curve makes some random lock on LP rewards, i'm sure somebody will just fork Curve and do a no lock LP rewards.

Everyone in this channel / industry is in it for the money including me u and the founder,  long term, short term, lock, no lock, value, no value, governance whatever is just a means to make more money.

I support everything that is voluntary and market based, just my 2 cents, I'm also a LP provider, haha.

Author: icecreamislife
Content: having a high quorum requirement on highly supported polls is redundant, and gas and time inefficient. but you need to protect against whales coming in and flipping at the last minute. a way to do this is to automatically extend the vote duration if the result flips within some closing window of the poll. i created a modified version of the aragon voting module that does this if interested (i think curve uses aragon in back-end?) - though it's reasonably trival change to make.

Author: ne1k0
Content: i believe this has been accomplished by decaying the voting power of a voter to a value of zero at the point of the vote expiration that way the vote time period is static.

Author: icecreamislife
Content: ah, interesting. thanks. do you have any references/docs/link on that? would be curious to learn a little more.

Author: axadep#6149
Content:
> ah, interesting. thanks. do you have any references/docs/link on that? would be curious to learn a little more.
@potander Yes, after half the vote time passes, power for that vote starts linearly decaying, you can see here

Author: axadep#6149
Content: https://github.com/curvefi/curve-aragon-voting/blob/master/contracts/Voting.sol#L432

Content: Along with other changes, described in specs

Author: procell247#7568
Content: are all code changes approved by the DAO audited before being released? It's great that there was an audit before launch, but I'm worried that as the DAO votes more and more stuff, code changes will be introduced rapidly that might introduce security issues in existing pools or at the protocol level that creates new risk for LPs

Author: charliecurve
Content: Yes everything is audited

Author: charliecurve
Content: Pools don't need re-auditing though

Author: charliecurve
Content: (As they will be the same code base most of the time)

Author: charliecurve
Content: Also the DAO parameters have been audited so that's covered

Author: charliecurve
Content: What would need audit is new lending pools or significant changes to the protocol

Author: charliecurve
Content: Also worth noting that existing pools cannot be changed so if that's a concern for you, you can avoid new pools

Author: procell247#7568
Content: that's good to hear

Author: procell247#7568
Content: how about the CIP to create a new compound pool that can claim COMP. will that be audited or is that considered a minor enough change that it won't be?

Author: charliecurve
Content: I believe that's been audited already

Content: so i was thinking.. PAX, BUSD, and HUSD all have fiat USD funds held by Paxos, so potentially a pool with these 3 assets only would have lower risk of loss? eg there's only 1 custodian to become insolvent, have a tech issue, or freeze the pool, vs several for all of the other curve pools

Author: monetsupply
Content: ppl (particularly weak kneed tradfi folx) might be more willing to invest in something like this, particularly if it was a no lending pool (even less contract risk)

Author: monetsupply
Content: i was also thinking about a pool with USDC/TUSD/PAX/GUSD for similar reasons - it only includes regulated stablecoins with accountant attestations etc, so traditional investors might find it easier to get on board. DAI, sUSD, and USDT present some exotic risks that I'm not sure everyone's ready for

Author: gczy#5289
Content: How do the gauge weight voting rules work if I lock more veCRV now but already voted last week? Am I still subject to the 10-day rule from the first vote or can I do a partial vote?

Author: kendrickllama
Content: you can only vote every 10 days for the same pool

Author: gczy#5289
Content: ok

Author: gczy#5289
Content: what's the rationale behind the 10-day rule? It creates a weird oscillating effect no? Basically every week a different pool of voters get to set gauge weights. Seems a bit odd.

Author: amplice
Content: @gczy only thing i can think of for why this gauge weight system works the way it does is to make people FOMO from pool to pool, increasing fees

Author: kendrickllama
Content: or it can work as a lever to direct liquidity from a pool to another pool: you have a new pool and want to promote that pool, gauge weight vote for that pool to attract more capital or you upgrade the contract of a pool and want people to migrate to that pool, gauge weight vote again for that upgraded pool

Author: amplice
Content: i'll concede the upgraded contract point @Kendrick Llama ğŸ¦™

Author: amplice
Content: but that can be done via governance

Author: amplice
Content: in the DAO

Author: amplice
Content: without the gauge weight system

Author: amplice
Content: i,e "do we want to add additional incentives for this pool because its been upgraded"

Author: amplice
Content: for promotion, again, that can be done via governance

Author: amplice
Content: unsure why its necessary to have weekly whale wars and even more volatile APYs on every pool with this gauge weight thing

Author: amplice
Content: rewards should be allocated by demand for the product to liquidity available ratio

Author: amplice

Author: pourteaux
Content: A comment on the different proposals for admin fee distribution:

Author: pourteaux
Content:
There are a few considerations, but I think the veCRV distributions make the most sense. The downside with veCRV distributions is that these are probably taxable events depending on your jurisdiction. The upside is that it encourages locking CRV to veCRV, and thus indirectly boosts the price of CRV by limiting supply. So, even if boosting the price of CRV is your primary goal, veCRV distributions will help. veCRV distributions are also good because they incentivize locking of CRV even beyond the minimum that will get you to a 2.5x boost. Furthermore, as your veCRV decreases with time, your boost doesnâ€™t change (unless you trigger a checkpoint). So absent veCRV rewards, there isnâ€™t much incentive now to extend the lock of your veCRV or to lock more CRV as veCRV beyond what will get you to 2.5x boost. With distributions, this changes.

Simply buying and burning CRV will more directly support the price of CRV and avoid taxable events. However if you take a longer term perspective, what is best for Curve.Fi is having tokens locked and people participating in the governance. Currently, people are selling their CRV beyond what is needed to get the 2.5x boost, or using that extra CRV to farm on cream.finance, etc. It would be much better for Curve.fi for this to be locked as veCRV. Whichever option is selected will have a big effect on user behavior, so we should select the option that will incentivize the most good behavior. In this case, that is distributions to veCRV holders.

Author: gczy#5289
Content:
> or it can work as a lever to direct liquidity from a pool to another pool: you have a new pool and want to promote that pool, gauge weight vote for that pool to attract more capital or you upgrade the contract of a pool and want people to migrate to that pool, gauge weight vote again for that upgraded pool
@Kendrick Llama ğŸ¦™ I have no issue with the gauge weight voting. I just think the 10-day rule does not work with the weekly re-weighting. I don't see how allowing people to switch their votes every week wouldn't accomplish the same thing. As currently constructed, I have to wait an extra week for any vote switch to kick in.

Author: ne1k0
Content:
You can switch your vote every week @gczy from what I understand. Changing your vote can happen any time, but voting for the same pool requires a 10-day wait period. This is to prevent accruing veCRV from effecting the weight of a set of pools from what i understand. Pools must wait to have the veCRV earned from them to re-reweighted towards it. Which makes sense.
If you want to switch from say ren to sbtc, you can change your vote no problem with whatever veCRV you have. But once you do, you must wait 10-days to re-weight your vote.

Author: 0xpigeon
Content: Has there been a proposal or discussions to change gauge weight voting? I'm thinking whether changing CRV emission weights to be in proportion to fee generation would be more beneficial to Curve.

Author: 0xpigeon
Content: Something along the lines of: the more fees a pool generates as a proportion of the total fees generated in curve, the larger proportion of CRV goes to that pool.

Author: 0xpigeon
Content: So for example if the Compound pool generates 15% of all fees in Curve, 15% of CRV should be allocated to that pool. This would incentivise more capital to flow toward useful pools, rather than pools that are voted for

Author: 0xpigeon
Content: What caused me to think about it was on DAI/USDC/USDT trades, they're almost always routed through sUSD pools probably as the transaction does not require wrapping/unwrapping of the tokens (which cost more gas). Though the pool APY would increase due to the fees, its effect on attracting useful capital is negligible as currently, CRV emissions form the bulk of LP returns, so LPs would look to go to higher CRV emitting pools instead of what is more beneficial to the protocol as a whole

Author: 0xpigeon
Content: (my assumption is of course that Curve as a whole benefits from the higher volume pools having higher liquidity. correct me if i'm mistaken)

Author: kendrickllama
Content: @0xPigeon this is actually a good one for proposal (I'm not sure about tech feasibility yet) but rewards based on volume utilization makes sense?

Author: wormholeoracle
Content: @0xPigeon  this is a great idea and makes a lot more sense than letting whales play games with the gauge weighting. I think part of the rationale for voting is that the DAO can assign more incentives to get liquidity in new pools. Maybe factor that into your proposal so new pools donâ€™t get shafted. Maybe a new pool is granted a baseline â€œpromoâ€?percentage of CRV distribution, and set a cap for how much CRV allocation can change week-to-week. That way a new pool has time to gain traction

Author: 0xpigeon
Content:
> Maybe a new pool is granted a baseline â€œpromoâ€?percentage of CRV distribution, and set a cap for how much CRV allocation can change week-to-week. That way a new pool has time to gain traction
@WormholeOracle yeah that's actually a good point. Perhaps giving the new pool 1 or 2 weeks worth of the "average %" of CRV emissions of existing pools (don't know how the math works out yet haha) until enough liquidity settles in.

Author: wormholeoracle
Content: Actually it should be based on liquidity utilization, pool with $10000 liquidity doing $10000 in volume is better than a $100,000 pool doing $50,000 in volume. Liquidity in the small pool is twice as useful (100% utilized compared to 50%) so CRV distribution should be 2:1 in favor of the small pool

Author: wormholeoracle
Content: This drives more liquidity to the smaller pool until its utilization is consistent with the other pools. This would help distribute liquidity most efficiently across all pools

Author: wormholeoracle
Content: That way a new pool can prove its value without needing to have massive liquidity, and wonâ€™t be neglected a share of CRV reward

Author: 0xpigeon
Content: ooh yeah that makes quite a bit of sense. However i'm wondering whether that would incentivise liquidity utilisation efficiency over..having a large liquidity pool for heavily used pools?

Author: 0xpigeon
Content: reason for saying this is that your proposed model would work very well when trading volumes are generally stable (or moving at a gradual pace)

Author: 0xpigeon
Content: but in times where people want to trade large amounts at short notice, smaller pools give larger slippages

Author: 0xpigeon
Content: so your model would incentivise these previously large pools to move their liquidity to smaller but more efficient pools, which i think would have a disadvantage of having larger slippage in times of sudden large volume/trades

Author: 0xpigeon
Content: and these guys may do their swaps elsewhere if the slippages are higher?

Author: 0xpigeon
Content: but its all conceptual, i'm a little sleepy and ideas take a long time to form in my head now hahaha

Author: wormholeoracle
Content: I guess the rationale is that if a pool has a higher utilization percentage than other pools, it _deserves_ a increase in liquidity so that it can better accommodate the outsized demand to use that pool. CRV rewards to those pools helps push liquidity where it is most needed

Author: wormholeoracle
Content: Deserve sounds like a moral thing, but I donâ€™t mean it that way

Author: 0xpigeon
Content: hahahah

Author: wormholeoracle
Content: If the CRV reward is based on total fees collected, it really prioritizes the titan pools. I could see a possible pitfall that liquidity would dry up on every pool besides a couple of the juggernauts

Author: wormholeoracle
Content: But you should def put a proposal out on this general concept of automating CRV distribution. The voting feels to me like a temporary solution and Iâ€™m not a big fan of it

Author: 0xpigeon
Content: yeah agreed. either someone with better english/math communications skills need to help me frame this coherently, or i need to sleep a little to get a bit more coherent

Author: wormholeoracle
Content: Lol maybe see if the sleeping helps, but Iâ€™m a fan of your reasoning so thereâ€™s that

Author: sjlee#1829
Content: I think using utilization ratio as a standard for guage weight is a good idea. But also it reminds potential risk. If we assume a small pool, cross trading could appear to dominate the guage weight, which is obviously not good.

Author: wormholeoracle
Content: You mean like wash trading? Thatâ€™s a good point. A small pool doesnâ€™t have to do much to fake volume and draw a large portion of CRV rewards

Author: wormholeoracle
Content: Maybe a formula that somehow combines total fees collected and liquidity utilization could mitigate wash trading without starving out the small pools?

Author: fieldg
Content: Metamask displays the worst case gas fee.  Actual gas charged is a runtime value, so there is no way to know a priori what it will be.  If you check how much you actually pay on the transaction, it will be much less

Author: Two Cell#4739
Content: A few questions - is anyone giving any thought to an eth/seth pool?  Even if synthetix didnâ€™t incentivize, it might serve as a nice alternative to the yeth vault and Iâ€™m not sure the systemic risks of synthetix is any higher than makerdao although i think it is hard to say as they are both complex systems.  Somewhat relatedly, Iâ€™ve heard Michael and others talk about meta pools.  To me, the holy grail of capital efficiency would be in addition to the current pools, also have meta pools that allowed me to take some of my btc, eth, or gold pool tokens, and some of my y,susd,compound pool tokens, and choose to market make with those.  How hard would this be?  If it could be done, it would make Curve into a one stop shop for most the asset types that matter and really drive volume I think.

Author: wormholeoracle
Content: So I think my criticism of the gauge weight voting is that there isnâ€™t necessarily any value creation tied to the proportion of CRV that is allocated to a gauge. Voting incentivizes participation in the governance for the selfish reason of maximizing CRV, but I think CRV should be allocated based on the performance of the pool

Author: wormholeoracle
Content: For instance, a pool that generates more in fees and more utilization Of pooled funds is more valuable to Curve overall. The LPs participating in this pool should be issued more ownership share because the value they give to curve is proportionally more than a pool with less fees generated and less utilized capital

Author: amplice
Content: ^this is exactly how i feel

Author: wormholeoracle
Content: CRV is an ownership share and I think it needs to be thought of this way, not as just an incentive to maximize yield

Content: @raddy some rough numbers about fees

Author: fessor63
Content: Charlie tweeted https://twitter.com/charlie_eth/status/1305895244274204675 that soon ~$40K per day gets allocated to veCRV holders (or is it 1/2 of that?)..  That's about $15 million per year.  The total number of veCRV is 5.6 million.  If nothing changes, the annual payout would be $2.7 per veCRV.  So if you take 1 CRV costing $1.60 and lock  it up for 4 years, giving you 1 veCRV, you'll start reeling in $2.7 per year.   Something's gotta give!  If fee flow holds up or grows, then either 1) CRV's gotta go a lot higher or 2) many more CRVs will be deposited into governance to dilute that cash flow.  If neither of those happens, then you'll have an ongoing >>100% annual return on CRV held in governance.

Author: ne1k0
Content:
I think a better calculation would be honest and assume that the veCRV buying from pool fees is the _only_ buying pressure. If that were the case than about $50k in admin fees would be buying what I think is a emission rate of 766k CRV a day.
Assuming a 10% lock rate (i think that's accurate?) that's 690k curve being bought with $50k every day, or making CRV worth ~ $0.07
While increased trading can boost this number, it's not a huge amount of pressure from what i can figure...it all depends on you own time horizon

Author: ziel_ny
Content: Has anyone considered making CRV a fee token (like BNB)? Use CRV for fees and pay less. That creates a nice incentive for platform users to buy CRV when it's low, to use it later when it's high.

Author: ne1k0
Content: I don't think there is much difference in charging a fee in $ then buying CRV with it, versus charging the fee in CRV to start is there?

Author: ziel_ny
Content: There is. You buy when it's low.

Author: ziel_ny
Content: And keep for later.

Content: doesn't that depress the value versus increase it?

Content: it you make them buy it at the time of trade (charge $) then it helps increase the value.

Author: ne1k0
Content:
I put this in the gov page, but thought I'd re-iterate here. I don't know if this was the intent or not (partly?) of gauge weight voting, but it provides a native way for a third party to sponsor a new pool with their tokens of interest in it.  I don't know if that's already happened with some of the latest pools, but if party X wants to have a pool with xToken in it, they know it'll only get liquidity if it has CRV allocated to it.
Thus they must go out and buy CRV on the market, lock it and then boost their interested pool. I think this is an awesome mechanism to allow someone to incentivize a pool in a native way (unlike SNX) and prop up the CRV price.

Author: charliecurve
Content: ^ Yes, it's definitely one of intent.

Author: charliecurve
Content: And I think it's already working, pretty sure Huobi are the ones boosting hBTC, that REN are playing a part in REN allocation. All protocols being considered for new pools (AAVE, dForce, Idle, pTokens etc etc) will also have reasons to allocate to their pools and there are already many forces at play on Curve (Synthetix, Binance, Huobi, Compound, Bitfinex, Ren, MakerDAO and others)

Author: charliecurve
Content: But I agree a performance based allocation mixed in would be nice

Author: charliecurve
Content: ie we don't want to have one of the protocols/cex above acquiring huge amounts of CRV and allocating CRV to their pool if it's not bringing protocol fees to Curve

Author: ne1k0
Content: I think there is currently some adversarial  feelings between LPs and pools they aren't a part of. I understand wanting it to feel more fair, but maybe once admin fee flow starts the "rising tides lifts all boats" mentality will set in and we'll stop having this fight over gauge allocation. Giving a little kick start to new pools that we aren't a part of should be encouraged, it's the trade fees we're after at the end of the day.

Author: charliecurve
Content: Yes, I think so. It's been weird seeing the push back on hBTC pool. I understand people don't like cex and particularly Huobi but at the end of the day, the fees are rolling in.

Author: charliecurve
Content: Once veCRV holders figure out that more pools and more liquidity is great then we can start growing. Not all pools will do $100M in volume per day but that's okay

Author: ne1k0
Content: That's been my one worry about the un-named fork; but they seem to be stuck on a single pool which will be their end once the ball starts rolling with new pools here.

Author: charliecurve

Author: michaeljohnx
Content: Hi is there any proposal or discussion on using individual locked veCRV to only boost our deposits, instead of the whole pool? I don't see why the whole pool should benefit from my contribution, in essence it feels like my veCRV is being diluted this way, no one else in the pool paid for it so why do they benefit? Maybe I am missing something here

Author: michaeljohnx
Content: or is it this way right now? Maybe I just misread something in another channel here

Author: ne1k0
Content: It does only boost your own deposit, are you conflating gauge weighting with boost?

Author: michaeljohnx
Content: thanks - yes maybe, can you clarify the difference?

Author: michaeljohnx
Content: I haven't played with gauge weighting yet, it seems somewhat redundant to have both mechanisms for boosting APR

Author: ne1k0
Content: locked CRV (veCRV) serves several purposes. The first being the obvious ability to vote for proposals. The second is to weight where the stream of CRV that gets "minted" every block goes, this is updated weekly and is the gauge weight. Voting for a pool here does lift the APY for the entire pool. The other use is for boost, this is the multiplier within the pool and only effects your deposits.

Author: ne1k0
Content: Gauge weight is a mechanism to incentivize liquidity to come and deposit in a particular pool. Boost is a mechanism to incentivize those LPs to lock their earned dividend.

Author: michaeljohnx
Content: ok, so gauge weight is only for CRV stream boosting, and the boost multiplies individual % of CRV and LP fees within each pool? or just the LP fees

Author: ne1k0
Content: Just the CRV, the LP fees are always fairly distributed

Author: Deleted User
Content: Hey guys, can't find the answer in docs. If im, locking CRV for 1/2/3/4 years, are the rewards that I'm getting claimable without lockup?

Content: You mean to ask, are the CRV earned from veCRV also pre-locked?

Author: Deleted User
Content: yeah, if I'm locking veCRV the rewards are claimable immediatly or they somehow restacking and locked for the same period? Also, what kind of rewards am I getting? trading fee only?

Author: ne1k0
Content: They're not locked automatically, I imagine it will be a similar claim button like on the minter page. Yes, 50% of the trading fees from all pools.

Author: Deleted User
Content:
> They're not locked automatically, I imagine it will be a similar claim button like on the minter page. Yes, 50% of the trading fees from all pools.
@ne1k0 trading fees according to a pool? e.g. usdc(yusdc) or CRV?

Author: ne1k0
Content: So, the pool fees are collected in the native tokens (usdc/dai/usdt or renbtc/wbtc for example); these are collected and at some point converted into CRV by swapping them for existing CRV on the market. How this works is I think being developed, and requires avoidance of front-running (e.g. you can't just buy CRV every 5pm on a friday in bulk).  But that's what's eventually distributed to you as a veCrv holder.

Author: ne1k0
Content: One idea is to have a CRV/ETH pool on curve itself which could provide liquidity to purchase from. One could take the CRV earned and either stake it for veCrv, or provide it to that pool which eventually will be bought back by admin fees and redistributed to yourself while also providing return in the pool itself.

Author: 0xnook
Content:
I am concerned about the increased acceptance and influence of tether given their lack of transparency. Right now the only stablecoin pool without exposure to it is the compound pool (which btw I would love to see a comp collecting v2). And well, with the 3pool based metapools idea, this includes most future pools. Also by locking CRV you cant avoid being mostly exposed to it.

I feel this is a trend in all the major protocols. Just recently it was enabled as collateral on MakerDao, it is one the incentivized pools in Uniswap, and it only takes a governance vote to have it enabled as collateral in Compound or Aave.

Taking Maker as an example, from a risk assesment of USDT:  

"Due to USDTâ€™s noted history of opaqueness and fractional reserve, we recommend an initial LR of 150%. This is the only parameter that can protect Maker in the instance where these risks materialize again."
https://forum.makerdao.com/t/usdt-pax-collateral-onboarding-risk-evaluation/3723/3

There are ways to mitigate a risk of USDT peg such as taking a permanent short position, but I feel that with time this is getting harder and harder, now even my DAI come with a small USDT exposure. Will it be enabled in lending protocols as collateral if time goes by without any incidents happening, but without improving their transparency?

After all, USDT has the highest liquidity, which can lead to higher fees. But I believe this quick rise of defi and open governance allows us to set the standard of what to expect from new and existing protocols, and we should be aiming higher.

Author: wormholeoracle
Content: Honestly I expect DAI to flop before USDT. Everyone wants to dig on USDT, itâ€™s the bogeyman of crypto for years now. Yes itâ€™s a risk- literally every asset Curve lists is a risk. Iâ€™d be happy to discuss the topic from the perspective that all pegged assets have risk profiles that should raise eyebrows, but Iâ€™m tired of hearing USDT be singled out in those discussions

Author: 0xnook
Content:
@WormholeOracle 
> Honestly I expect DAI to flop before USDT
I hope not ğŸ˜… , but I agree that synthethix assets like DAI could carry greater risks.

I think it is more fair to compare it to other "custodial" stablecoins. I cannot make the claim that USDT is scam, but I do feel like the lack of transparency is offputting, and would rather support other assets. For example I really like how Sogur (a small SDR pegged coin) provides daily proof of their reserves. I feel that if the market would demand more transparency, this could be the norm. After all they all serve the same use case. 

I am not aware of the risks of other stablecoins (except maybe DAI and sUSD), would like to hear what you think.

Author: chazzy17
Content:
please help me firm up my understanding of metapools
metapools are separate liquidity pools with a new asset and the liquidity provider token of a different pool (e.g. mUSD / 3Pool LP token)
with withdrawing/depositing from the source liquidity pool happening during swap transactions?

Author: chazzy17
Content: are metapools eligible for gauge weight votes like all others?

Author: jiecut#9734
Content: @chazzy17 Yeah, there'll be a gauge for [gusd, 3pool]

Author: chazzy17
Content:
so depositing 3pool liquidity to a metapool shrinks the 3pool liquidity
liquidity providers to a metapool are exposed to the additional token and do not receive trading fees from trading activity of the 3pool

Author: chazzy17
Content: correct?

Author: jiecut#9734
Content: @chazzy17 Yes, it'll shrink 3pool liquidity if you sell half your 3pool lp tokens.

Author: jiecut#9734
Content: @chazzy17 Liquidity providers to a metapool still receive trading fees from the 3pool. I don't think they'll receive CRV rewards from the 3pool gauge though.

Author: chazzy17
Content:
@jiecut thanks again suppose im not grasping how "meta" these pools are
what happens when you trade GUSD for USDC through the GUSD/3Pool metapool?

Author: jiecut#9734
Content: I think you grasped it. GUSD to 3pool swap, then 3pool to usdc, like a withdraw to only usdc.

Author: chazzy17
Content: yes alright thanks for the confirmation

Author: chazzy17
Content: so the gas used for swaps against a metapool will be similar to a typical token swap on curve (no wrapping/unwrapping) plus a single asset withdrawal/deposit from the 3pool

Author: thelonious_cr
Content: Hey everyone, if I understand correctly 50% of all fees are going to veCRV holders right? This seems like a very bad idea. This scares away LPs who are the real ones you want to attract, and with less liquidity, less trading, less fees, and with less fees $CRV price continues to dump. I think token holders got greedy here and shot themselves in the foot. Taking something like 10% of fees would be fine, but 50% is crazy, the fees should be there to attract liquidity! Not everybody wants to hold CRV and participate on governance and a lot of people just want some good returns for their liquidity, are just using yearn vaults and will move away from Curve if those vaults start paying a lot less that other options. Just my thoughts,

Author: charliecurve
Content: @Thelonious_Cr DAO wants to incentivise people who are willing to hold and lock CRV

Author: charliecurve
Content: So I think it makes sense

Author: .nagaking
Content: @Thelonious_Cr As more people lock veCRV, profits will begin to be diluted, driving people back to LPs. Eventually some equilibrium will be reached in terms of APY. That's how I see things at least (not an expert)

Author: .nagaking
Content: The other factor is that more people locking veCRV would drive up CRV price. So the expected dynamics are likely a bit complex

Author: charliecurve
Content: I think that sums it up nicely

Author: c2tp
Content: ya.  in replacement of fees, the dao is paying LPs with gov tokens.   the other option is 0 gov tokens and full fees (aka before dao happened).  either way the LPs are getting paid

Author: .nagaking
Content: @C2tP Good point. I personally like the fee splitting approach because it aligns the interests of LPs, vote-lockers, and traders. Easy to imagine a virtuous cycle there

Author: fessor63
Content: On the Stats page, it says "The chart shows only trading volume fees and does not account for fees from deposits/withdrawals."  Are there "deposit/withdrawal" fees?  Maybe that just means that if, say, you deposit 100% USDC, then Curve does some trading for you to give you the pool's weighted mixture of USDC, USDT, DAI, and whatever, and charges the standard 0.04% on that trading.  Anyway, are "deposit/withdrawal" fees a significant source of revenue compared to the ordinary fees that are shown in the chart?

Author: kendrickllama
Content: there's a 0.02% swap fee when you deposit/withdraw from the pool

Author: fessor63
Content: Oh, didn't realize that -- and that's true even if you deposit pool-proportionate amounts of each stablecoin?  I wonder if those fees are significant source of revenue.

Author: kendrickllama
Content: yes because it's like the 0.04% trading fee but split 50/50 for deposit and withdrawal from the pool (because you essentially do a swap when you deposit/withdraw from the pool)

Author: JohnnySokko#3864
Content: Since I am new to Curve and after having locked my CRV away for four years (still feels a bit crazy) and having read some of the discussion around how to return value to CRV owners, has it been discussed to just provide a mechanism to the normal CRV holders to earn yield by supplying and staking to the Uniswap LP? Possibly using the Ampleforth Geyser model to incentivize longer term commitment using a multiplier that increases over time to a set max. I really like the idea of gaining the 2.5x bonus and trading fee APY with veCRV but I also dislike the dropping CRV value. The veCRV program is great from my pov however it is something that appeals to a small % of folks given the complexity and commitment. Perhaps some of the fees can be directed toward an easier to understand and lower commitment program with lower but acceptably sized rewards to get additional CRV off the market and also increase liquidity?

Author: JohnnySokko#3864
Content: I've locked my CRV up for 4 years which was a tough decision to make but I did it however I was thinking about that commitment even with the rewards/benefits that it comes with it. That it can seem daunting given how fast things move and how CRV has been in a perpetual downtrend for even the shortest commitment time of one week. Has it been discussed and would it be a possible option to replace the one week with an flexible option with the same rewards without any commitment at all? I'm thinking about it from a human behavior standpoint that any commitment that you have to lock things up for any amount of time is "tough".

Author: JohnnySokko#3864
Content: The benefit would be that more people would go ahead and stake their CRV knowing they get a reward (reduced as it is) with the flexibility to take it out at anytime without a lock in period. Given that one week is so short anyway I suggest this might result in more staked CRV without undermining the intent of the program

Author: Collin#7715
Content:
> i mean... the system obviously still works without the token, nor is it a goal to require it.  what are we comparing to? its not a utility token like LINK etc
@C2tP comparing it to a "work token" where the token is used to generate value to the system. for example SNX token is used as collateral in their system. If i can be honest, the CRV token is just a "rent extraction" because it is sucking away fees meant for liquidity providers. Put it another way, CRV tokens caused some of the fees meant for LPs to be taken away. 

To create a more valuable CRV system, we need to find better uses of the CRV tokens which will add value to the Curve system instead of extracting value/fees away from the Curve system. 

How to do it? I'm not sure. I'm just sharing my thoughts here to see if anyone has any good suggestion.

Author: Collin#7715
Content:
> well definitely hope we dont take MORE away from LPs (cip23)
> 
> im down for other uses though indeed.
@C2tP  I have to push back on this. Suppose an LP is getting 30% APY (CRV) at current $0.40 price. If you cut the distribution by half, the APY drops to 15%. But what if because you cut the distribution by 50%, the selling pressure reduces significantly and price doubles to $0.80? The APY is back to 30% again. Because the distribution is in CRV tokens and not fiat, the APY depends on the price on CRV tokens. Therefore there could be a positive feedback loop. It is hard to gauge the effect of this though, which is why I suspect that a number of whales/people did not vote ğŸ˜…

Author: c2tp
Content:
- sell pressure doesnt reduce because its just going to  someone else
- you take an immediate *guaranteed* loss for a long shot *maybe* return back to normal
- there is no positive feedback loop

a positive feedback loop would be like giving crv to traders so they get near free swaps, this increases volume on curve because it beats everyone else,  increase volume on curve means more revenue, more revenue means a better crv price because revenue shares. better crv price means LPs keep their APY.  it completes a nice loop.

in your example what happens?
you shift crv to vecrv holders,  they mostly sell just the same as LPs because theyre taking profit on their 4 year locked tokens,  price doesnt change much,  LPs get less and remove liquidity.
i just dont see it making the platform of curve stronger. 

like lets say crv price jumps 100% tomorrow.  what happens? does that make the platform stronger?   more LPs will come back because APY is better now.  more people will sell though instead of locking too.   having lots of liquidity is great though dont get me wrong.  but the focus should be increasing revenue. and that could be expanding the swap services or even creating something new etc.   this, in turn, will create value for the crv token.   revenue is literally the only thing that gives crv value

Content: shifting CRV to veCRV makes locking up CRV tokens more attractive because it increases the APY tremendously. the current daily admin fee is $12,000. just shifting 10% of LP's reward to veCRV is 76,000 CRV x $0.40 = $30,400. Author: fomofrog
Content: Great conversation so far.  What about some sort of curve interest rate based on needed liquidity? Example. If the liquidity used is 70%, the paid interest on said pool should increase as well until something like 40%.  If there is no usage of a pool, the interest rate goes down dramatically until the volume increases. The boost can be increased to 5x instead of just 2.5x giving those with locked crv more incentives, but overall reducing interest based on volume/lp usage

Author: GG#3628
Content:
$ 300,000 a day is a huge number. With the price reduction, you can only pay temporarily. And finally, if the investor does not make a profit, he remove the capital. The solution in my opinion is:
1 Locking is a good idea. Which is being done.
2 Price reduction also reduces pain in the short term.
3 It should be sought to get cheaper capital such as getting from the bank. Another way is to collect multiple smaller stable coin and pay low interest in stable coin.
4 With such a large capital flow, the profit received ($ 12,000) is very small. The main reason is your systems are not simple and not famous.
5 Need a strong partner to solve problems. And thinking and feasibility studies should be done in this field.
6. When someone is falling, he should not make a late decision at all. Paying such a huge amount of money every day breaks almost every waist.

Author: steveo_
Content:
Personally, to see if veCRV was a good investment for *me*, I did the following:
1) Get my share percent of veCRV locked vs. total veCRV locked
2) Get an average of new veCRV minted daily (around 300-325k veCRV) week over week
3) Assume 1% volume growth (for gauging veCRV rewards, which is 50% of total Curve fees * share percent)
4) Extrapolate that out through end of year

Author: Collin#7715
Content:
> Your not changing the total amount of crv though so in the end nothing's changed. It's still being diluted at the same rate
@C2tP if a company has 120m shares outstanding and announce that it will be issuing 2m/day new shares to outsiders. within 1 year, existing stakeholders would see their ownership drop from 100% to 14%.

Assuming that the 2m/day cannot be changed, one way to reduce dilution is to issue some of it to existing stakeholders (eg 50% or 1m/day to existing stakeholders). within 1 year, existing stakeholders would see their ownership drop from 100% to 57%.

(im simplifying the calculations. for the 2nd scenario, the actual % will be lower than 57% but much higher than 14%)

Author: c2tp
Content:
@Collin 

fell a sleep so sorry to bring this up again but...

we'll probably endlessly disagree as i see:
1. any minted crv as normal inflation no matter who's hands it goes to.
2. also that its an immediate guaranteed hit to LPs with a hope for a possible price recovery = risky move.
3. risky mechanic since people with vecrv can just continue to increase allocations to pump their bags with crv to cover apy droppage while LPs continue to be the only ones to take the hit. (like businesses laying off staff during a down turn but board members still get bonuses)
4. price may dip but focus of further development should be on increasing curve revenue, thus things like this are a distraction from what's important.

now that being said, this is obviously just how i feel and opinions differ. However, if the votes go in favor of cip23 i suggest the following be added to the proposal.

- gauge claims directly to vecrv and NOT crv (using Voting contract's deposit_for() function)
- a max weight can not be assigned in the gauge controller, so the gauge itself could have a max weight settings and anything assigned over that gets redistributed or burned.  setting this max weight would require real proper votes and not weekly gauge weight shenanigans. this could at least mitigate damage from imbalanced gauge weights giving too much to the vecrv pool.


feel like if this middle ground was implemented then at least some of my concerns can be mitigated, but obviously im still a "no" as i think it will only hurt curve

Author: JohnnySokko#3864
Content: I don't quite understand why this is a binary choice as this happens in the TradFi world without any ill effects that I have noticed when companies pay out a dividend to shareholders. This is usually a very low rate however it does make it far more attractive to certain investors. Granted we might want to start slowly and not go to a 30/70% split right away and might want something far less aggressive like 5 or 10% to gauge its beneficial or ill effects. I doubt such a low number will cause any disruption to the LPs but would funnel (I think) at 10% and current prices double the veCRV incentive which would result in higher lock up rates and potentially a stable(r) which would offset the LPs loss.

Author: hikariws
Content:
I think CRV shouldn't inflate, it's like a company freely emitting more stocks and diluting investors shares and forcing those who wanna keep their shares to keep buying more stocks.

I think that buying CRV should have been directed into investing on features development and innovation on Curve, on its early dates. Now CRV buying is pure speculation. Ppl who buy CRV now isn't contributing to pools liquidity, which is the business here, but they are earning half of pools fees. While LPs, who actually invest on the business, earn only half of fees, and are also incentivized to buy CRV instead of putting that money on pools, while many of them aren't willing to participate on governance.

If most attention goes to CRV, as its holders manage the business, we will lose sustainability and liquidity.

Author: tian7.eth
Content: If anyone has any query demand just publish it here. I am glad to practise my query skills and help others tooğŸ˜

Author: tian7.eth
Content: And you can also get the average gas costs for depositing in a curve pool. I query the tri-pool and get 0.02ETH cost on average.

Author: tian7.eth
Content:
```select avg((a.gas_price*a.gas_used)/1e18)  from curvefi."dai_usdc_usdt_evt_AddLiquidity" t 
inner join ethereum."transactions" a on a.hash = t.evt_tx_hash
where t.evt_block_time > now() - interval '1 days' ;```

Author: wormholeoracle
Content: Anyways, the point I keep going back to and this is the last Iâ€™ll say about it: organizations are a collection of individuals and provide some benefit to those people, otherwise theyâ€™d go to another organization or go out on their own. We are unfairly prioritizing individual users with this whitelisting. An organization deserves the same rights when using our platform because at the core, theyâ€™re just a collection of people that operates through representation rather than directly. Not only do I feel morally obliged to make this point, I see that in the future, a majority of our engagement will come from organizations. Itâ€™s more efficient, thatâ€™s why people organize. We do ourselves a disservice if we donâ€™t choose to support this evolution toward more organization. I think we will be replaced by a more aggressive version of curve if we insist on prioritizing individual users

Author: fomofrog
Content: There's a line between centralization and decentralization. At a point, an organization of individuals will have more voting power than even whales. It's somewhat similar to the UNI governance where 2 entities control the vast majority of the delegation. Then they proposed to lower quorum, had they won, they would be able to propose and push through whatever they wanted that would best benefit them (Dharma and Gauntlet)

Author: fomofrog
Content: I think if individuals wanted to be able to vote, feel free to join and lock crv. We know entities will only vote in their best interest. Just look at what a whale did to 3pool and busd pools in the last day

Author: fomofrog
Content: Anything that may be a threat to curves ecosystem should be evaluated

Author: JohnnySokko#3864
Content: I don't think we have delegation of voting in our roadmap and since I'm fairly new this might have been voted down but I think at scale this is something I believe should be considered.

Author: ne1k0

Author: ne1k0
Content:
So, I think it was Kawar that talked about this auction that a harvard professor would do where he'd auction $20 off at the beginning of each class. The catch was the first and second bids both had to pay, and what would frequently happen is two people would be caught in a sunk cost bidding war paying well over the $20 each to win.

So, if you turned this into a smart-contract, do you think people would participate and get sucked into the same thing? Would you bet anything for 10 ETH if the rules were that you either (A) won or (B) got your money back if you weren't 2nd place?

Content: if I deposit DAI in this pool, will I be able to withdraw the same amount of DAI later, regardless of the price of DAI?

Author: jiecut#9734
Content: @Cryptonic no

Author: cryptonic.
Content: is it then best to reduce exposure by contributing proportionally the coins as per the pool composition?

Author: dasismoose
Content:
If you deposit any coin into the pool you can withdraw any coin from the pool.  Eg 3pool can deposit Dai USDC usdt 

You could put Dai in because there is a bonus for doing so

And then later withdraw usdc because there is a bonus to that as well.   

Bonus indirectly relates to amount of each coin in pool.   Less Dai in pool = better bonus for deposit and vice versa.

Author: c2tp
Content:
Probably more of a #general  question but when you deposit dai you get a usd value representation of your dai.  Then you exchange that usd value back into whatever coin you want when withdrawing.
Point is your value should be the same (or grow rather from fees)

Contributing in a single coin results in a trade underneath to make your position balanced so if you have the coin you can deposit all together in proportion. But wouldn't worry about it too much and just deposit what you have

Author: cryptonic.
Content:
with DAI it matters though as the price fluctuates a lot
if you bought your DAI "expensive" and provide to the pool at an unfavorable time, you lose and it will take quite some time to recover
so timing is for sure relevant

Author: c2tp
Content:
Your basically selling the dai for "virtual usd" then claiming it back when you exit
All that matters is if you bought expensive you deposit while still expensive.
If you bought expensive and price dropped after that.. well doesn't really have anything to do with the pool per say as the value already decreased.

If you bought low and dai spikes to like 1.1usd though you would lose out on that movement if you were in the pool

Author: cryptonic.
Content: but you realize gains / losses when entering / exiting the pool

Author: ne1k0
Content:
> I will get the increased amount of CRV APY applied to future CRV rewards in THIS Pool for THIS amount of LP, correct?
@Cryptonic that's true. As long as you don't deposit/withdraw/claim on the gauge it is static for the most part.
> if I now increase my funds as LP, the boost % will go down proportionally,
Assuming you only locked just enough for the original LP? Assuming the pool is the same size (ish) then yes. If the pool shrinks or grows it could change how much veCRV is required for you LP boost (in a positive or negative way).
> what happens if I withdraw my LP position
Boost is agnostic to pools

Author: hikariws
Content: I understand that our locked CRV is used equally on every pool we deposit

Author: ne1k0
Content: You'll get "boost" across all pools you provide liquidity to, it's not "targeted" So you can have more LP if you split it up potentially; fully boosting each pool.

Author: ne1k0
Content: But a lower boost on some pools may still yield better and/or expose you to assest you don't want exposure to. So it's a personal calculation.

Author: cryptonic.
Content: ok so basically locked CRV can be utilized freely as boost across all pools

Author: ne1k0

Author: cryptonic.
Content:
so say I lock just enough CRV to boost my current LP in BUSD
Now I add LP to COMP, then I need additional CRV locked to get boost there, otherwise, it boost proportionally both pools by 50% less each

Content: No; it'll just get boosted too and won't effect busd.

Author: ne1k0
Content: You may find it cheaper to buy less CRV initially and split the LP between pools. They could both be fully boosted with less initial CRV

Author: ne1k0
Content: Only your share of the pool size and you share of veCRV goes into the cacluation; for each pool independently

Author: cryptonic.
Content: I guess I need to understand then still the difference between CRV and veCRV

Author: ne1k0
Content:
CRV is a token that is given to LPs as a reward. When you _lock_ it, it becomes instead a balance on a lock in the DAO; the CRV is put in a lock account with the rest of the CRV that was locked. It can't be withdrawn till the lock expires that locked it.

veCRV is a calculation that is basically 1 CRV for 4 Years == 1veCRV; with a linear slope (so 1 year is 1/4 veCRV).

Author: ne1k0
Content: It is this calculation that goes into how much weight your LP has in a pool (all pools); and how much weight your vote is in the DAO

Author: cryptonic.
Content: does locking CRV trigger minting veCRV tokens?

Author: ne1k0
Content: No, purposefully it is not a token, but a balance in a huge hashtable

Author: cryptonic.
Content: ok

Author: ne1k0
Content: Linked to your account which can not be transferred

Author: ne1k0
Content: Since it decays, it can't really be a _normal_ token or a _balance_ really.. It's a calculation based on lock time to expire, and CRV balance in the lock.

Author: cryptonic.
Content: linked to account as in wallet address

Author: ne1k0
Content: Yes. Ethereum *account*

Author: cryptonic.
Content: what if I change my wallet address for whatever reason within those 4 years

Author: ne1k0
Content: Then you'll need to start a new account if you want any LP it provides to get a boost. There *currently* is no mechanism to transfer or delegate in anyway.

Author: ne1k0
Content: It's a bummer, one that I recently had come up in a big way. But it's not there to be a pita; it's meant to prevent a veCRV market from making the lock meaningless

Author: cryptonic.
Content: so its basically tied to the wallet address forever

Author: cryptonic.
Content: forever as in for the lock period

Author: ne1k0
Content: Yes.

say I would need to lock 20k CRV today to achieve max boost given pool size and LP
If I do it 1 month later with identical parameters, will I need more CRV to do the same due to inflation?

Author: ne1k0
Content: Unknown...

Author: ne1k0
Content: If the pool grows by 100x by then, then no. You may already have enough to fully boost.

Author: cryptonic.
Content: no same poolsize, same LP

Author: ne1k0
Content: If the pool remains the same, then if the lock rate exceeds the decay rate then yes.

Author: cryptonic.
Content: just sheer inflation

Author: cryptonic.
Content: i think decay rate not yet clear then

Author: ne1k0
Content: Say you put in 1000 CRV for 2 years? It would give you 500 veCRV. A year later you'd have 250.

Author: ne1k0
Content: You can always move your lock out though, so you could lock it for 2 years, and every week extend it a week so that after a year it's still 2 years out and you still have 500veCRV

Author: cryptonic.
Content: Right so the boost doesnâ€™t last for the time, it decays and to refresh you need to continuously lock more

Author: ne1k0
Content:
Well, yes and no. Because of the way it works under the hood it's not continuosly recalculated. That would be too expensive to do in the code.
Instead everytime you interact with the gauge (add more LP, remove LP or claim the CRV itself) the boost is recalculated and stored on the chain itself. It then stays the same till you interact with it again.

Author: ne1k0
Content: So if you boosted to 2.5x, and just walked away. It'd stay there till you claimed the accumulated CRV.

Author: cryptonic.
Content: Gotcha

Author: cryptonic.
Content: Thanks for the detailed explanation very helpful

Author: johnny_f
Content: You can also extend the lock of the existing veCRV. So if you take ne1kO's scenario from above, you could increase the lock duration to 2 years again at any time and then have the 500 veCRV again

Author: cryptonic.
Content: right, without having to add more CRV

Author: johnny_f
Content:
the APY number on veCRV is not fixed *for you* though, even if it stays the same.
Scenario: you buy CRV to be locked at 0.4 per CRV and gain 100% APY on it. You get paid the 3CRVLP tokens for it that week.
Next week: CRV is 0.3 and still 100% APY. 100% APY on 0.3 is only 0.3 though, so for your base price of 0.4 these 0.3 gain are 'only' 75% APY actually, even if it is displayed as 100% (because it takes the current price as basis, not yours). You get paid this 75% 3CRVLP tokens for that.

Author: ne1k0
Content: For the week I think it was somewhere around 70%, but I'd have to check.

Author: cryptonic.
johnny_f

Author: johnny_f
Content: so it's all based on your assumptions if this is worth it

Author: jiecut#9734
Content: So APY is variable. Better way is to understand where it's coming from. It's coming from 50% of all transaction fees. Transaction fees are 0.04% of volume.

Author: johnny_f
Content:
> This is what businesses do all the time because it helps them grow and itâ€™s good for shareholders
Yes, but businesses buy back and especially issue shares only very rarely (even TSLA does that two times a year maximum) while CRV issues new CRV at an insane rate every day. It's not really comparable. Companies don't dillute by 50% each year, but maybe 1-3% if they really need to.

The amount of fees generated, assuming you take half from the 0.02% which are intended for veCRV holders, is so small that this won't even make a dent in sell pressure compared to the newly issued CRV.

What I see the effect of the CRV buybacks: temporarily buys with funds which were taken away from veCRV holders, which would otherwise have got them. And then they're held in the fund. So veCRV holders can watch the CRV which were supposed to be for them get less valuable in the fund. If veCRV holders wanted to do this, they already can. This is just a way to *force* them to do it.

Author: johnny_f

> personally I'd be fine if my veCRV pay went like 10% into DCAing CRV

Perhaps the only thing that would be nice is an automated mechanism for continuous compounding effect for those that intend to use admin fees to lock them asap for more veCRV.

Author: Collin#7715
Content:
Integrating yearn and compound introduces risks into the curve system. it increases the APY but at the cost of additional risks. Should we consider remove such features?

Risks are amplified when you build on top of a system. You are increasing risks exponentially, not linearly.

Author: wormholeoracle
Content: while that yearn exploit would have been 'good' for LPs and veCRV because of trade fees, I think it's worth considering ways to discourage these attacks from going through Curve. I think we owe it to the whole ecosystem that we put effort into being unfriendly to exploits

Author: ne1k0
Content: I don't know how you distinguish "legit" use and "exploited" use from a 3rd party?

Author: wormholeoracle
Content: Maybe a surge fee that makes trading in a pool very expensive after it passes some utilization threshold. In the case of the harvest incident, the utilization was well over 100%

Author: ne1k0
Content: The "exploiter" will be fine to pay those fees with others money...??

Author: wormholeoracle
Content: they made money off the arbitrage. if the fee is higher than the payout, cant exploit it

Author: ne1k0
Content: An arbitrage that was using the wrong prices for the bonding curve is my understanding.

Author: wormholeoracle
Content: yeah they did massive volume on the y pool to move prices so they could use the manipulated prices to pull out more than they put into harvest

Author: ne1k0
Content: The arb may still exist in the exploited code all while our fees are getting higher and higher

Author: wormholeoracle
Content: i dont know if it would effectively stop an attack, but when you have utilization that is really high like it was in the harvest incident, it's a pretty good indication that its not organic volume

Author: ne1k0
Content: It just feels silly to basically put up a daily trade cap on each pool; the LPs are "good" for the day? They don't want to continue to trade the market's demand at an attractive price?

Author: wormholeoracle
Content: in normal circumstances the cap is never going to be reached

Author: ne1k0
Content: It just feels like it's not our problem to solve and we shouldn't have to accomodate everyone else

Author: ne1k0
Content: I understand the sentiment, and in an ideal world nobody would be enticed to use an exploit, but that's not this world ğŸ˜¦

Author: wormholeoracle
Content: It's worth considering for our own protection as well. If there's unusual activity that is stealing money from our LPs, we would ideally have some mechanism in place that recognizes this and freezes the pool

Author: wormholeoracle
Content: our protection right now is limited to a human controlled emergency dao that I dont even really know what their power is. I dont think they can even freeze trading unless its a new pool

Author: charliecurve
Content: The freeze pool thing is a myth. If there any value in attempting to do it then protocols would try but there is a reason nobody does.

Author: charliecurve
Content: Regarding the harvest thing, I'm truly sorry some people lost money there but I have to agree with @ne1k0, the security of other protocols isn't our problem. Curve behaved as expected during that night, someone took advantage of a design flaw that has nothing to do with Curve.

Author: ne1k0
Content: @WormholeOracle in this example the exploiter focused on a single pool; they could have done this in each of the pools Harvest was exposed to but they didn't. If we had restricted Y pool in someway, and the exploiter had a target of $20M profit (or whatever it was); they would have just continued on other pools. In the future if Curve is not enough to handle the demand including exploiters on the market (because of liquidity or artificial restrictions), others will provide the market for them and the trading will just go there.

Author: ne1k0
Content: Curve can't be the Flex-Tape of the defi ecosystem

Author: wormholeoracle
Content: I think it's good for building adoption if we can create some assurances for people who use Curve. 1. LPs know that they are insured against curve smart contract risk. 2. Lps know they are insured against stablecoin peg risk. 3. LPs know Curve is protecting against market manipulation. If we keep acting like this is the wild west and everyone is on their own, how can we expect the ecosystem to mature?

Author: ne1k0
Content: I completely agree that there are many LPs that would exist that don't now if there were insurance. But this is another lego that is not "Curve" per say. By not having it be part of curve LPs can choose if they want to reduce their yield by lowering risk buying insurance with some defi-lego.

Author: wormholeoracle
Content: I'd prefer insurance was the default condition and LPs can choose to opt out. Obviously we're not there yet but I'd like if it was so easy to be insured, most people would just choose to go with it

Author: ne1k0
Content: That's semantics; but as you point out, the more complex a protocol becomes and integrates with other _things_ the more it's exposed. So I like to keep Curve focused on doing what it does really well. If we want to make a CurveProtect product that LPs can also participate in, that's cool.

Author: ne1k0
Content: But it should be a different _thing_

Author: wormholeoracle
Content: I'm not really talking about curve making an insurance product. I mean integrating with an existing solution. What would ideally be an existing solution, anyways. because really nothing exists at the scale we would need it to right now

Author: ne1k0
Content:
Unless the insurance is trusted, then i'm still just as exposed to smart contract risk (even more so since now i have smart contract insurance too that could fail).
You can eliminate most risk to stables by supplying the ones you trust to a money market and borrowing those you don't.

Author: ne1k0
Content: You pay interest to do this; consider this your "insurance" rate.

Author: wormholeoracle
Content: you can offset some risk doing this. But if you have 3 coins in a pool, you can only guarantee yourself to recoup 1/3 of your deposit in case of a default

Author: ne1k0
Content: ?? If I deposit 100% USDT to 3pool, and it "defaults" i'll be left with USDT to withdraw. I can use that to pay my loan back...there's no 1/3 anything

Author: wormholeoracle
Content: right but what if DAI defaults

Author: wormholeoracle
Content: you lose 100%

Author: wormholeoracle
Content: or you can borrow 1/3 DAI, 1/3USDT, 1/3 USDC and you have a promise of getting 1/3 back if any defaults

Author: wormholeoracle
Content: better than 0, but not really a perfect insurance policy

Author: ne1k0
Content:
Sure; yes you're right. I guess I see what you're describing as a function of yearn or pickle; something that wraps up curve into an "easy" button. Let them do that, it's proving very difficult.
For those that have the ability, you can use Curve directly and build your own financial products.

Author: teemulau#7395
Content:
Does anyone else feel that the market in general has a black spot in understanding how APYs are generated? I'm referring specifically to the word "staking" that can be divided into 2 different components:

1. The "2017"-style staking, which is simply non-dilutive in PoS /DPoS style systems, where by participating you are "earning" staking rewards, which actually just offset inflation. No additional value in created here, and it is simply a way to maintain consensus in L1.

2. The "2020"-style CRV staking where you lock tokens to *earn actual fees/cashflows/dividends/earnings from fundamentally valuable activity by offering external users a valuable service in exchange for these fees*

Using words like "fees/cashflows/dividends/earnings" when referring to 1. is a huge smoke and mirrors strategy that even today some of the L1 projects are using to confuse people and make them invest in their shitcoins.

To me it is clear that 2. is the market potential that many are dismissing as "another APY promise", but in fact this is the golden goose. This is the untapped holy grail in crypto, real cash flows & dividends that make companies fundamentally valuable.

UNI & other blue chip DeFi projects will join Curve to activate admin fees, and at some point the market will probably understand all this. Until then, I'm accumulating & locking long-term with this strategy.

Author: ne1k0
Content: @teemulau add on top the realization that all of the cost to conduct business is put on the customer directly; there's no "overhead" to the business that exists, just future growth investment.

Content:
But couldn't that be beneficial to the protocol overall?
The vault still creates demand for CRV, and the risk of locking tokens for years is eliminated. This could bring people who were not comfortable with that ?

Author: johnny_f
Content: there are a lot more complex tradeoffs here, of course. My individual veCRV can be used to boost my LP stakes in different pools. I can't do that with yveCRV.

Content: not sure if that's a positive

Author: zurnai#4971
Content: So many variable honestly haha

Author: johnny_f
Content:
Right now, as an individual I ahve the advantage that I can boost my LP rewards, while all the yearn/harvest & co vaults have a hard time doing it.

If yearn now can reach 2.5x boost for all their vaults, while only giving up 10% of the 'native' APY from the vault to the yveCRV vault... why would I ever lock up my veCRV? I'm rather sure I'll not be around in 4 years (thats a HUGE time in crypto... everything can change. Try to name some top 10 coins from 4 years ago without looking it up).
Also I wont have to babysit my LP any more or take care about selling CRV, it's automated in the vault then. Plus no more veCRV final lockup as yveCRV holder.

Whitelisting smart contracts moves the incentive from being in a better position as individual who cares to... automated, huge farming vaults. Not sure this should be incentivised.

Author: johnny_f
Content:
Seen from a personal perspective

yveCRV advantages:
- can be freely traded
- earns more from admin fees than veCRV because it also gets 10% of the yield from the yearn vaults it boosts

yveCRV disadvantages:
- cannot be used to gain personal boost

yveCRV risks:
- voting power concentration
- the locking up idea is no longer necessary if yveCRV can be freely traded: if yveCRV existed when i started using curve, I'd not have locked up my personal CRV then
- that increase in boost for yearn will more than double their CRV selling (assuming their boost goes from less than 1.25 to 2.5)

Author: zurnai#4971
Content:
Ok, letâ€™s say Iâ€™m a newcomer looking for yield.
If we ignore the interactions between LP and veCRV lock for boost for the moment (would make it even more complex)
My options are:
On Curve directly:
    (1)    LP for fees and CRVs
    (2)    Buy and lock CRVs for fees
On Yearn:
    (3)    LP in automated vaults ïƒ?can dominate (1)
    (4)    Lock CRVs in Backscratcher vault ïƒ?dominates (2)
    (5)    Buy yveCRV on the market ïƒ?value of yveCRV > veCRV = CRV locked 4 years
veCRV must be at a discount to yveCRV, because yield is lower, but also because it includes the risk of a 4 year lock.
However, veCRV enables you to get CRVs back after lock (negligible for now in my opinion, as 4 years is an eternity)
Large discrepancies between CRV prices and yveCRV price could be arbitraged away depending on the yield differences and (subjective) risk of lock.
Weird thought, but all in all, has Yearn just â€œacquiredâ€?Curve?
Please correct me haha, the picture is much larger I know

Author: johnny_f
Content:
> I could be wrong, but my sense is that the common strategy of vote locking the minimum to attain full boost, then selling the rest for more stable/btc to LP with will continue to be more profitable
@nagaking 
It is more profitable right now, *if* you ignore the following:
- gas costs of claiming & selling your CRV
- gas costs of re-distributing to different LPs
- costs of having to lock up veCRV (basically, you can assume a value of 0 for those) while in in yveCRV you can get back their current time value at any point in time
- convenience of not having to babysit your position

I believe for the vast majority, going the yveCRV route and 2.5x boosted yearn vaults will be superior

@WormholeOracle If you want to use btc usd price to calculate wbtc trading size. You can refer to @axadep 's dune query.

Author: tian7.eth
Content:
```select date_trunc('day', evt_block_time) AS day, sum(tokens_sold/(case 
when sold_id = 0 then 1e18
when sold_id = 1 then 1e8
end) * p.price) as hbtc, 0 as sbtc, 0 as ren, 0 as susdv2, 0 as busd, 0 as y, 0 as usdt, 0 as pax, 0 as compound, 0 as TriPool from curvefi."hbtc_evt_TokenExchange" as cst
LEFT JOIN prices.usd_2260fac5e5542a773aa44fbcfedf7c193bc2c599 p ON p.minute = date_trunc('minute', evt_block_time)
group by 1
```

Content: ah, yeah. though i struggle with this one. People seem to think this requires an Oracle, but an Oracle just gets it's pricing from the Bid/Ask of an order book. You don't _need_ an order book to generate a spot price.

Author: .nagaking
Content: Currently working on AMM design that takes volatility into account

Author: .nagaking
Content: I agree with both sides here. AMMs as currently designed can't avoid impermanent loss. But with a little creativity I believe they can

Author: .nagaking
Content: An ideal AMM would essentially be a smoothed approximation of an order book. The bonding Curve shape should basically be the opposite of a natural order book shape. High volatality = spread out orders = thinner bonding curve. Low volatility = orders tight around the avg. price = wider bonding curve

There had already been a discussion about a CHF (Swiss Franc) pool. But the Sygnum stablecoin (DCHF) did not match due to KYC. 
we may have another solution; xCHF/sCHF

Author: 0xnook
Content: I think how safe tether is is not the only important thing to consider, it is also about what kind of practices are supported by the industry

Author: 0xnook
Content: But I have already expressed my views on that :P

Author: robin_9447
Content: what do you mean by that @0xnook ?

Author: 0xnook
Content: Well, I am referring to the lack of transparency of the tether reserves. Is the largest stablecoin and the only one that gets away with 0 transparency. I think this is due to it being the first one, but feel like it is being more and more cemented into the defi ecosystem by protocols building on top of it.

Author: 0xnook
Content: I think it doesnt need to be that way

Author: 0xnook
Content:
In other protocols is less concerning, on lending protocols like Compound or Aave, USDT is not allowed as collateral, other AMM dont have the metapool structure so you have way more choses on where to LP without being exposed (still dissapointed USDT/ETH was an incentivized pool on uni). 

But on Curve there are barely any options without being exposed to it, and I feel like given how large of a building block and how essential curve is becomming to mantaining stablecoin pegs, and how if one coin looses peg all of them are affected, it is specially important to provide more options in this protocol.

I have seen comments on how DAI is more likely to loose peg, and that might be right, but at least if it fails it will be with publicly auditable code and governance, not by placing my trust on the hands of a company that works in the dark.

Content: DAI collateralized by DAI is quite reasonable. It's even safer for liquidations because there's less pressure on the peg.
