Author: goldenhat
Content:
Maybe an unpopular opinion: have people discussed the option to have a pool with custodial only USD tokens ? PAX, USDC, GUSD would be a good related pool.

Motivation: one day, it is likely to see regulations that will attempt to make minting USD tokens illegal if they are not baked by real USD and in a way that can be audited. This may not happen very soon although It may happen one day. The main reason could be that the US gov will want to control the minting of dollas as opposed to allow minting via collateral at Synthetix, MakerDAO, etc.

It also seems that the official digital doller will be minted by the Fed potentially. This would further increase the probability of regulation of tokenized dollars on blockchains.

Personally I would like to see DAI, sUSD etc succeed. Although it may be beneficial to prepare for the outlined case above. Not sure when the right time will be to have such a custodial only pool. Just sharing the idea for consideration.

Author: marcel_j
Content:
New to Curve. Want to learn about the governance of the DAO.

Does the governance process work in the following way?

Basically structured forum posts + Signalling via Snapshot (CIP proposal) requiring a minimum of 2500 veCRV.
If the off-chain passes, the team/multisig is responsible for implementing the changes.

Author: mimaklas
Content: https://resources.curve.fi/guides/voting

Author: marcel_j
Content: Thanks for pointing that out, i mixed them up. What can the DAO votes do? I wonder for example, what if in a few years, there needs to be a token swap. Could a DAO vote do that?

Author: ne1k0
Content: It's not off-chain with a team/multisig. it's a real DAO, the off-chain signal is just a process to allow those with < 2500veCRV to make a proposal or for those that would like feedback before moving to a proper on-chain vote.

Author: ne1k0
Content: New pools are created after a signal vote, because they don't initially get any of the CRV emissions; that still requires an on-chain vote.

Author: kidkrypt0
Content: https://twitter.com/lidofinance/status/1342136265005817856?s=20

Author: kidkrypt0
Content: isnt 400k well short of reaching a quorum?

Author: ne1k0
Content: Yes.

Author: kidkrypt0
Content: Thought so, was a bit confused when the curve twitter retweeted this, i hopped in the lido telegram chat to tell them the proposal didnt actually pass will see if they get the message

Author: ne1k0
Content: It's 5% of the total veCrv at time of the snapshot to be precise.

Author: marcel_j
Content:
Yeah I did not see the on-chain proposals at first. Glad to see it exists.
But what powers does the DAO have? Anything beyond setting parameters and creating pools? What about a CRV token swap? Could the DAO deploy a new token contract?

Author: ne1k0
Content:
It's actually *not* the DAO that creates pools. The development team does at some direction of the DAO via the signal votes. Think of this as where DAO gets influence in the priority that the development team does.

What the DAO does have control over is the community fund of CRV, the emission weights to the pools, the addition of pools to the gauge controller, parameters on the pools (fee rates, admin rates, A parameter etc),  Emergency DAO members, whitelisting of smart wallets, and ownerships of the contracts.

Author: ne1k0
Content: As per could the DAO convert to a new CRV token; I'm not sure. I haven't studied it enough to know honestly.

Author: marcel_j
Content:
What a thorough answer. Are you part of the team?
And Is that information (e.g. whitelisting of smart wallets governed by the DAO token holders) on the website/resources?

Author: ne1k0
Content: No, not part of the team. It's not well documented what I describe above; mostly just what I've gleened from looking at the code and observation of the process.

Author: c2tp
Content: you couldnt use a "new crv token" in the current dao because that doesnt make much sense but theortically you could make a NEW dao with a new token and provide a conversion from old crv to new crv.   and then slowly migrate everyone over

Author: marcel_j
Content: Why doesn't that make much sense? What if you require new features, or want to migrate to a new token standard (e.g. ERC777) hypothetically speaking?

Author: marcel_j
Content: I more and more understand what the devs of DFOhub mean when they say a DAO is very unflexible an basically leaves a multisig in charge for the most crucial updates.

Author: wormholeoracle
Content: There is def a learning process about how best to make use of a DAO. But in curves case it canâ€™t be updated by multisig. There are some powers given to an emergency DAO to halt trading but they canâ€™t push updates

Author: wormholeoracle
Content: Iâ€™m actually in favor of the DAO delegating to ppl and teams, instead of requiring direct action:

Author: wormholeoracle
Content: https://gov.curve.fi/t/scip-21-dao-role-delegation/1188

Author: marcel_j
Content:
So that proposal claims the DAO can create new pools. @ne1k0 says otherwise. Where is the contract that deploys new pool contracts?
Can you point out how that works? Contracts are in Vyper, I am not familiar with the contracts.

Author: ne1k0
Content:
Pool creation obviously requires coding the contract itself and deploying it; neither of which the DAO can do. The development team AFAIK has control over a pool registry here (https://etherscan.io/address/0x7d86446ddb609ed0f5f8684acf30380a356b2b4c); they can add and remove pools from an abstraction layer that other projects use to discover the pools with a versioned API/ABI.
Those then are live and the assets it was written for can be deposited and swapped, however they do not receive any incentive from the CRV emissions until they are "blessed" and added to the gauge controller by the DAO.

Author: marcel_j
Content: Okay, so the flow would be: anyone can write and deploy a pool but it needs to be added to the registry to be used.

Author: marcel_j
Content: But it's not the DAO voting on a new pool to be added.

Author: marcel_j
Content: I am member of the DFO community, and basically, with a DFO you vote on smart contracts. So some community member, or a multisig, or a DAO, could write the pool contract and create a proposal (=code). After a successful vote the contract gets referenced by the proxy contract and is thus part of the dApp.

Author: ne1k0
Content: Anyone can write and deploy a new pool yes. That's just something Ethereum allows and cannot be prevented right? It sounds like DFO is concerned with the listing process of contracts; whereas Curve is concerned with contracts being integrated into the economics/tokenomics of the protocol.

Author: ne1k0
Content: For instance, the white-listing process is there to prevent the tokenization of veCRV itself. Not to sit on some high-throne and pick winners and losers.

Author: ne1k0
Content: The development team provides the pools, and the participants of the DAO decide how to incentivize said pool (if at all) through voting.

Author: ne1k0
Content: You or I could also write a pool and put it up for inclusion, in fact you're incentivized to do so through the community fund.

Author: charliecurve
Content: Anyone can deploy a pool, yes

Author: charliecurve
Content: In fact there's technically no need for a vote to do so

Author: charliecurve
Content: The DAO votes on adding gauges and directing the CRV inflation

Author: fomofrog
Content: @C2tP BAC is the stable coin in a multi-token algorithmic stable coin. BAB is a bond for debt should the peg of BAC stray to far below 1 Dai, BAS is the Seigniorage Share for expansion should BAC goes too far above 1 Dai. They help maintain peg should BAC start to de-peg with game theory and incentives by expansion and contraction.

Content: This is intentional, to prevent swapping/selling of veCrv as an asset

Author: 0x_zack
Content: I suppose the CRV tokens can be redeemed (with fees accrued along the period) when lockup period is over. How can we redeem them? Usually in other protocols we have some staking tokens like stkAAVE in aave, etc. to do it?

Author: ne1k0
Content: The lock has a hashmap of your ETH address to a CRV balance/Expire Time. Once it's ended you'll be allowed to withdraw the CRV from the lock.

Author: ne1k0
Content: No staking token required to redeem them

Author: ne1k0
Content: just the same address

Author: 0x_zack
Content: Ok I see thanks @ne1k0

Author: ne1k0
Content: Your trading fees earned from locked CRV are delivered on a weekly basis: https://resources.curve.fi/guides/claiming-trading-fees

Author: 0x_zack
Content: Is it possible to get veCRV lockup tenure beyond 4 year?

Author: schoad
Content:
no. but you can extend the locking period again to 4 years.

locking longer would not yield you more veCRV. as 4 years => 1 CRV = 1 veCRV

Author: 0x_zack
Content: Confused. So I will get the same voting rights and boosting yield no matter I extend the lockup period or not?

Author: schoad
Content:
4 years are the max. if there would be no timelimit, one could lock 1 CRV for infinity and get infinity amount of veCRV.

*infinity = max time supported with used timeformat

Author: 0x_zack
Content: I see what you mean. Thanks.

Author: 0x_zack
Content: Just to confirm, if I lock my CRV for 4 years today. In a month, my voting weight will be down 1/48, correct? @schoad

Author: schoad
Content:
exactly. it will continuously go down to zero ending in 4 years.

thatâ€™s why you should periodically extent the locking period. but always keep gas fees in mind.

Author: 0x_zack
Content: I was trying to extend the lockup period on https://dao.curve.fi/ but I don't get a lot of choices.. @schoad

Author: 0x_zack
Content: I mean I can only extend the lockup by a week?

Author: domob
Content: You can extend to any date until now in 4 years.  I guess you just locked a week ago?  Then indeed you don't yet have many options (but you also need not extend yet I guess)

Author: 0x_zack
Content: I see thanks a lot!

Author: schoad
Content:
this. as I mentioned, it does not make sense to extend the locking period weekly. this would cost you a lot of gas for negligeable benefits.


nonetheless, if you have a very high stake, weekly extension still might make sense.

Content:
Personally I would love to have a way to directly allocate part of my salary to a trustworthy CHF stablecoin without going the route of a $ denominated stablecoin. 

If I pay most things in CHF, I donâ€™t want to risk devaluating my savings / investment due to USD devaluation against CHF. And this happened in the past from 1.60 CHF to 0.80 CHF per Dollar. Same happened with GBP and EUR.

Content:
I'm in a similar situation.  While I do get my salary denominated in Euro for a bunch of reasons, I have to pay most things in CHF and for that reason, Euro and CHF are what I keep my reserve liquidity in.  With the EURS pool, I now have a way to store some EUR in DeFi; a CHF pool would be the counterpart for it.

Author: uxt
Content: Given the recent "regulatory inquires" leading to the shutdown of the DMM DAO, it seems prudent to take inventory of CRV DAO risks.

Author: uxt
Content: I believe CRV is one of the most protected projects from this type of situation, since we have embraced true decentralization to a large degree. Decentralization is the key.

Author: uxt
Content: The code is available, and the pool contracts are disowned.

Author: uxt
Content: However, there are still apparent risks to major contributors. Do the non-anon CRV core contributors operate from a relatively friendly jurisdiction (non-us/china, mainly)? How about the frontend infra?

Author: uxt
Content: No need to necessarily answer these questions if it's sensitive, but something to consider going forward. I don't think DMM will be the last, and CRV doesn't need drama.

Author: MasanobuFukuoka#0871
Content:
ICHI (ichi.org) believes that every crypto project deserves their own in-house stablecoin that fueled by their scarce coin. We have created stablecoins for Bitcoin, Ethereum, Chainlink, and Wing.finance (an Ontology project) in just 2 months.  These stablecoins are minted for exactly $1 of value but also 300+% over-collateralized with their target cryptocurrencies.  There are no complex algos or lending markets.  There is no chance of liquidation.  These stablecoins are redeemed for exactly $1 of USDC.  

ICHI will make a lot of stablecoins and Curve is the ideal platform to swap between them.

What is the best way to begin to engage with the Curve community to evaluate the partnership potential?

Author: jimmyd#6021
Content: That is the question I raised in the proposal and signal pool to discuss and vote

Author: gunboats69
Content: contact @Charlie and he will help you setup the proposal

Author: monstcas
Content: Stablecoins are cool and all but "every crypto project deserves their own in-house stablecoin"

Author: monstcas

Author: monstcas
Content: I don't want to have to do loads of research for 100 different wrapped BTC

Author: aviova#3056
Content: I get your point.  Wouldn't it be nice if everyone would just agree to use your coin?  Unfortunately, different crypto projects exist for many different reasons and it is impractical to ask them to exit their economy to support your coin.

Author: monstcas
Content: I don't get it though? You can use USDC in any project, if you want a decentralised one you can use DAI

Author: monstcas
Content: Your project is not going to create a more secure USD than DAI

Author: monstcas
Content: Your project is not going to create a better WBTC or renBTC

Author: monstcas
Content: It's like using a library in code, you shouldn't reinvent the wheel unnecessarily and code your own lib if someone else has done it better with longer history behind it

Author: MasanobuFukuoka#0871
Content: Curve would make a ton of fees with swapping and risk isn't as bad as you think ... With ICHI, you will put in parameters and get out a stablecoin contract.  One audit applies to all of them.  And you can view the treasury reserve ratio to understand risk at a glance.

Author: MasanobuFukuoka#0871
Content: You have to sell the project's scarce token to use USDC.  You have to buy the project's scarce token to mint its oneToken (ICHI stablecoin).  It is that simple.  Every project founder we talk with instantly groks this point.  The bonus is Curve would make an enormous sum on swapping fees.  In your future vision, there would be no reason to swap between stablecoins and Curve makes very little.  In that outcome, everyone would use USDC and reward the future shareholders of Coinbase with the locked fiat.

Author: gunboats69
Content: ICHI and CLAW (soon) is locking token within their system and leverage to other yield-seeking opportunity

Author: MasanobuFukuoka#0871
Content: just to be sure we have the same understanding: ICHI is the governance token of the ichi.org community and platform.  The ICHI community enables other communities to govern their own in-house stablecoin (ICHI oneToken).  ICHI decides the allowed oracles, collateral, investment strategies, etc in exchange for protocol governance rewards.  The ICHI token is hard capped at 5M tokens.  What does CLAW do?

Author: gunboats69
Content: It a stablecoin from BADGER

Author: gunboats69
Content: same idea right?

Author: MasanobuFukuoka#0871
Content: I just looked it up.  There are two big differences: 1) You borrow CLAW.  This means there is a risk of liquidation ğŸ˜¢  There is no risk of liquidation with oneTokens :yes:  (ICHI stablecoins)  2) You must be over-collateralized to borrow CLAW.  This means you pay more than $1 for a stablecoin ğŸ˜¢   You pay exactly $1 of value for oneTokens :yes:

We have a proposal in the Sushiswap community because it is so powerful for AMMs.  Today, people must sell CRV to deposit back into your platform.  They would need to buy (or have) CRV to deposit oneCRV into your platform.

Author: jimmyd#6021
Content: The issue is not to have the most secured stable coin, the issue is to have the best proportion secured-flexible. To issue 1 bn new DAI you need at least 2 bn dollar equivalent of crypto native assets to be locked, which means your money supply for economic activities in Ethereum is capped by the value of assets settled in here. So DAI is secured but is not capable to boost the expansion. USDC has regulatory risks and crypto economy bares the tradFi risks in it.

Author: jimmyd#6021
Content: The idea of new currencies is to have something like banking multiple when $1 of initial monetary supply results in $5 in financial transactions. However, we should be more humble and reasonable with regard to the way the money is created to not be in the same hole like current governments

Content: FRAX stablecoin is a way more fair to the end users than USDT.

Author: dzhurinskiy
Content: There are couple of additional features that differentiate FRAX from other stablecoins worth to mention: 1. Interest bearing collateral (makes the protocol even stronger in the long-term), 2. Plans to diversify collateral so that not only USDC is used (minimization of regulatory risks).

Content:

Author: ne1k0
Content: Yup, and veCRV < 0.01; because veCRV decays with time. It _would_ be 0.01 if your lock expired 4 years from *now* not from 27/02/2021 as your screenshot would indicate.

Author: hujeth
Content: I have locked 4th march

Author: ne1k0
Content: Right, but the expiration time was set to 2/27/2025 since the lock has to land on a thursday. It has been a couple weeks since then so it's not 0.01 voting power anymore, you'd have to extend the lock expiration to last thursday to get back to 0.01; then you'd have to continue to do this

Author: teemulau#7395
Content: So... what are the thoughts of UNI v3 here?

Author: teemulau#7395
Content: It's relevant in the sense that how much do Curve see Uni now as competitor for stableswaps?

Author: bosstweed1
Content:
not sure, from my initial thoughts it seems less financially enticing on both sides? (fees for the trader are a minimum of 0.05% which is more than Curve) & (seems like being a curve LP is still better with all the CRV rewards, and more volume because of low fees?) it also might be scarier as a trader doing a $60mm swap on uniswap because at the moment it's not clear to me how obvious it will be to see where LP's have their price bands set, and i wonder if there could be some crazy slippage scenario where you execute near the same time or just after a huge LP withdraws, i guess there can be max slippage guardrails in place

the other interesting side of this is how Curve is getting more into cross asset swaps through synthetix(is the overall fee for that less than 0.30%?), so while uni is crawling into curve's space, curve is also crawling into uni's.

Content: Looks like sCRV will be a thing soon, got me thinking about two types of compounding interest opportunities. 1 CRV-sCRV pool with gauge. 2. Instead of claiming CRV rewards, there could be an option to â€˜Compoundâ€?where the CRV is claimed -> auto traded -> sCRV -> sUSD -> 3CRV -> stake in gauge. And you could swap sCRV to sETH, sLINK, whatever underlying youâ€™re providing liquidity on.

Author: Jaqen#8180
Content:
Hi Guys, i got one question regarding veCRV voting power decrease,  is that means the boost power will also decrease ? 

Another question is after 4 years lock, i will able to get back the CRV i locked ?  Thanks!

Author: ne1k0
Content: Boost will only decrease when/if you claim or stake/unstake from the gauge. Otherwise no it does not decay as veCRV does continuously.

Author: ne1k0
Content: RE: 2nd question. Indeed.

Author: Jaqen#8180
Content: Thanks, you mean claim the reward , and stake/unstake LP ? or more veCRV

Author: ne1k0
Content: I mean your _boost_ is calculated everytime you interact with the gauge itself; whether it be to claim the CRV earned, or to deposit/withdraw LP from it. Doing so will recalc your boost with _current_ veCRV; otherwise it would continue to be whatever was calculated last time you interacted with it.

Author: ne1k0
Content: Adding more CRV to your lock will not cause this to be recalculated. Should your boost go _up_ / _or_ down due to the current state of the pool or your own lock, it needs some interaction to take place.

Author: Jaqen#8180
Content:
got it, so the boost calculated by the ratio between i locked compared with total locked correct ? 

And every time i interact with gauge,  it will be re-calculated . 

So my locked veCRV will be decreased linearly over the time?

Author: Jaqen#8180
Content: the reason i ask is pickle is doing similar , just want to make sure crv and pickle are doing the same or there is slightly difference

Author: ne1k0
Content:
Yes to the "decrease linearly over time" and "every time I interact".

Kinda for the "ratio between locked and total locked". It's also effected by your pool ownership ratio.

Author: ne1k0
Content: If the pool were to increase in size even with your decay and dilution as more people locked total crv; it could still be a larger boost if the pool size increased.

Author: Jaqen#8180
Content: got it, another question is about weekly fee , the reward will also be decreased since my veCRV is decaying?

Author: ne1k0
Content: Well, assuming the same trading volume week to week; yes.

Author: ne1k0
Content: that's kind of "the bet"

Author: Jaqen#8180
Content: yeah, and this is not depending on if i interact with gauge or not, correct?

Author: Jaqen#8180
Content: only hardcore defi users love Curve !  use Curve is like playing a game. need to spend time to know how to play the game .  ğŸ™‚

Author: ne1k0
Content: no, that's calculated using your veCRV total at the moment someone calls the snapshot/distribute call every week. This value is used for the incoming week to determine your share of all fees.

Author: Jaqen#8180
Content: i see, so the reward sharing will decay on weekly basis

Author: ne1k0
Content: Assuming others are locking > $CRV every week proportionally to you. You are not the only one experiencing decay.

Author: Jaqen#8180
Content:
hmm, got it so if no one lock CRV last week, i will get same proportional reward. 

if more people locking, proportions will be decreae, as my share is decreaed ?

Author: Jaqen#8180
Content: so it is all about shares of the total locked CRV.

Author: ne1k0
Content: Yes; _or_ if they extend the expiry period on their existing lock.

Author: ne1k0
Content: You can do that every week as well and maintain ~4years with no real decay

Author: Jaqen#8180
Content: how to extend the expiry period?

Author: ne1k0
Content:
This is what Convex and Yearn will do; so it will make the decay feel worse than it had previously since not everyone extends their lock continuously.
On the DAO minter or lock page. You can pick a new expire date.

Author: Jaqen#8180
Content: oh, you mean without lock more CRV, as long as i keep hit 4 years lock time every week, i could get no decay ? but just extend the period forever

Author: ne1k0
Content: Exactly, you'd never be able to sell/transfer the CRV used under the lock, but your veCRV power would remain the same absolute number.

Author: Jaqen#8180
Content: got it, thanks for the advice ,  so Convex and Yearn is not able to do that. correct ?

Author: ne1k0
Content: Do what?

Author: Jaqen#8180
Content: keep renewing expired data

Author: ne1k0
Content: Oh, I'm sure they do constantly; it's in their best interest since they've already committed to it being locked in perpetuity.

Author: ne1k0
Content: At least weekly just before the snapshot for the next weeks fees.

Author: Jaqen#8180
Content: oh, got it

Author: Jaqen#8180
Content:
thanks a lot for the info. so basically in summary for weekly fee, there is no decay as long as i keep renew weekly.

For pool boost, it will reduce the boost if i interact with gauge .  however if i keep renew it, the boost will be also same ?  ( assume pool liqudity has't change )

Author: ne1k0
Content: And assuming total veCRV is not increasing yes to both.

Author: Jaqen#8180
Content: got it, thanks a lot for your time.

Author: curmudgeon#3557
Content: anyone who's paying income tax wouldn't know the value of a veCRV that they receive because it's not a traded asset. it's clearly worth less than veCRV because it's a one way valve (the option to sell it is worth something). Also you could get into a situation where you owe income tax on veCRV that you can't liquidate to pay those taxes. What incentive would you have to opt in? I guess it's convenience, save gas, and instantly accrue trading fees. You don't get the boost adjusted til you claim on an gauge even if you lock more the manual way.

Author: raddygg
Content: You would owe no tax on veCRV

Author: raddygg
Content: That's part of the appeal

Author: raddygg
Content: You would owe when you claim your CRV at a future date

Author: raddygg
Content: Convex farming would only change slightly

Author: raddygg
Content: They'd be receiving cvxCRV basically instead of CRV

Author: raddygg
Content: But there would be less spot CRV to dump

Content: this is how i understood it

Author: raddygg
Content: one of the defining characteristics of ownership is "ability to sell"

Content: maybe your selling crv for vecrv at a price of zero (so capital loss of 100% - tax harvest?) and then later redeeming crv 'as an airdrop' with a cost basis of zero (so capital gain of the value of your crv tokens at time of being redeemed). But of course you don't redeem them and instead extend your lock to enjoy guage boosties

Author: nealmcspadden
Content:
If you're a US taxpayer, that's exactly what happens. You have a capital loss of 100% when you spend your CRV for veCRV. The flip side is when you unlock your CRV from veCRV is you have 100% ordinary income. But that's a problem for future bahjiggyboo.

Source: Am tax accountant

Author: kryok22#1611
Content: Do you not think that taking 100% capital loss immediately on your CRV locking to veCRV is an extremely aggressive position to take? I realize you can't effectively transfer your veCRV position, so you are stuck and it is illiquid, but the simple comparison I'd make is to buying a variable rate CD from a bank that restricts your ability to transfer/withdraw for a defined period of time. You would certainly not be able to take a capital loss immediately on that transaction.

Author: curmudgeon#3557
Content: My intuition agrees. If i invest in a private fund structure with a hard lockup or an invest/harvest period, i don't think I could claim a loss. Not a tax accountant, but I've seen all kinds of unintuitive things in terms of taxes, both to benefit and detriment of taxpayer.

Author: nealmcspadden
Content:
Not really. It's part of the consequences of crypto being regarded as property. You exchange CRV with a market value at the time of vote-locking for veCRV which has no market value. So effectively you're spending it and getting nothing back. You'll have a capital gain event between whatever you acquired that CRV at and 0.

But like I said, it all comes back when you redeem your CRV when the lock expires. At that point you have ordinary income in the amount of the market value of CRV at that time as opposed to capital gains

Author: nealmcspadden
Content: It's a consequence in the same way that there is no wash sale rule for crypto because it's property. So if you're down on a purchase, you can sell and buy right back to lock in a loss

Author: nealmcspadden
Content: This is different than putting money into a bank CD because dollars are money

Author: kryok22#1611
Content: Seems more like changing your ownership, rather than a sale. If you amended the terms of an existing LP investment in a private fund so that you could not transfer or withdraw for 4 years, would that have similar consequences? (Also not a tax accountant, and that hypo might legitimately have complicated tax consequences that I have no idea about! Just trying compare)

Author: nealmcspadden
Content: Actually, you don't even get veCRV. You receive a claim on veCRV

Author: kryok22#1611
Content: Well just because there is no veCRV token, that doesn't seem all that impactful.

Author: nealmcspadden
Content: No, your investment in a private fund is an investment of money.

Author: nealmcspadden
Content: (unless using a mark to market valuation method and the lack of liquidity creates a change in market value)

Author: kryok22#1611
Content: Well I'm thinking for an individual cash basis taxpayer.

Author: kryok22#1611
Content: In both scenarios, (1) cash is used to acquire the initial property (CRV or LP interest) and (2) then some "change" happens to make initial property nontransferable (vote locking CRV or amendment to partnership terms). I don't follow the distinction about how one is an investment of money and the other is not.

Author: nealmcspadden
Content: Because crypto is property

Author: nealmcspadden
Content: It's just a fundamentally different thing

Author: nealmcspadden
Content: I bought a chair. I gave the chair in exchange for the promise of a chair in the future. I no longer have chairs

Author: kryok22#1611
Content: and an LP interest is not?

Author: kryok22#1611
Content: Maybe an LP interest is a security, but I did not think so.

Author: nealmcspadden
Content: LP (assuming you mean liquidity pool) is a sale of whatever you put into the LP for the LP token

Author: kryok22#1611
Content: Oh

Author: justwanttoknowathing
Content: Under that interpretation couldn't you just deploy a wrapper contract that accepts token ABC, returns you wABC (a wrapped version that is not traded / has no market), claim a capital loss of 100% on ABC... eventually realize the value of ABC as ordinary income at some point in the future when you unwrap?

Author: raddygg
Content: typically trading a capital loss for future income isn't super desirable

Author: nealmcspadden
Content: Theoretically those have the same value

Author: kryok22#1611
Content: No i mean a limited partnership interest

Author: nealmcspadden
Content: Ah

Author: kryok22#1611
Content: In a private investment entity

Author: kryok22#1611
Content: woops!

Author: nealmcspadden
Content:
So in a limited partnership your interest is property. Your basis is your capital contribution. So if you sell your interest you have a capital gain event. 

If something internal to the partnership reduces the value of your interest, then there is no event until you sell

Author: nealmcspadden
Content: (or declare worthless)

Author: nealmcspadden
Content: You could, yes. It's really open to abuse ğŸ™‚

Author: kryok22#1611
Content: Yeah, it would seem very aggressive to me.

Author: nealmcspadden
Content: The reverse is also true

Author: nealmcspadden
Content: Create a new token

Author: nealmcspadden
Content: Trade $1 for 0.0001 tokens. "Pay" someone 100 tokens. Instant tax problem for that guy

Author: kryok22#1611
Content: Would you treat providing liquidity and receiving LP token (liquidity providing token) the same? Those LP tokens often have no market for you to sell them.

Author: raddygg
Content: eh you can make a liquidity case there

Author: nealmcspadden
Content: liquidity pool tokens are bought and sold between you and the platform yeah. It's a capital gain event each time

Author: raddygg
Content: the fair market mark price is where you could disburse not just the CoinGecko mark or whatever

Author: kryok22#1611
Content: Agree with raddy. In that scenario, I doubt "that guy" is going to claim on his taxes that the token you gave him is worth so much based on your one sham trade.

Author: nealmcspadden
Content: Sure

Author: kryok22#1611
Content: And I think he'd be justified in doing so.

Author: nealmcspadden
Content: But if you were malicious about it you could issue a 1099

Author: kryok22#1611
Content: Haha yeah

Author: nealmcspadden
Content: I'm not saying do this, I'm saying it could be done

Author: raddygg
Content: I did really prefer the "receiving veCRV" thing

Author: raddygg
Content: would have saved me a fortune on taxes ğŸ™‚

Author: nealmcspadden
Content: Crypto as property has all kinds of weird consequences

Author: kryok22#1611
Content: Sadly no like kind exchanges

Author: nealmcspadden
Content: Heh, the like kind exchange argument was always faulty. Even before it was restricted to real estate a key element of like kind is that you can't touch the money

Author: justwanttoknowathing
Content: That kind of issue makes me really suspicious that any tax authority would agree with the interpretation. It can't be trivial to defer all tax liability to the future.

Author: nealmcspadden
Content: Well 99% of people "in crypto" treat them like stocks. It's not that big an issue

Author: nealmcspadden
Content: If/when there is, case law will be discovered

Author: nealmcspadden
Content: Until then, wild west

Author: kryok22#1611
Content: Yes, definitely a individual risk decision about whether you want to shovel hundreds of thousands of capital gains into a veCRV investment pay zero in taxes

Author: kryok22#1611
Content: To me, seems like you'd be asking for an audit

Author: kryok22#1611
Content: At least in the US

Author: nealmcspadden
Content: Like I said earlier though, the only rational way you'd do that is to boost your earnings. So you'll end up with a net positive gain anyways

Author: nealmcspadden
Content: Anyhoo, dinner time ğŸ‘‹

Author: STAGHA#4583
Content: I did some research on the FRAX pool. My conclusion is this: Basically, the entire supply of FRAX is controlled by a few stakeholders. 96-98% of the FRAX supply is in pools, with the FRAX3CRV pool being the largest with 62%. Almost the entire FRAX3CRV pool is controlled by the AMO curve, which in turn is controlled by FXS holders. A look at the initial distribution of the FXS shows that 35% belongs to investors and the team. 60% should be distributed to the community through various programs, but the recipients of these programs are the initial stakeholders. Now comes the important part: The Curve AMO creates new FRAXs and pools them in the FRAX3CRV pool, stakes the LP tokens and collects the CRV yield. What happens to the CRV returns? The CRV are sold in the open market to buy FXS and then burn them. The idea is to generate the CRV returns through an artificial pool and to give FRAX investors the opportunity to slowly sell their FXS. Why is FRAX remaining stable? Because the supply is controlled exclusively by a few stakeholders and AMOs and these are controlled by FXS holders. Therefore, no bank run can happen: Because nobody owns FRAX worth mentioning except the FXS holders themselves. In my opinion it is a dirty game and serves to save investors from a completely lost investment by using an artificial curve pool to generate CRV returns in order to slowly buy out investors. If this is true, it is also a failure of the CRV community, which awards the FRAX Pool comparatively high CRV incentives.

Author: arcology0
Content: just curious - how is this different from any other project? almost all projects are not decentralized in a manner where you have no say unless you are a whale or have huge pools of capital. what would be a similar assessment of Curve look like?

Author: RamanBindlish#8948
Content: Hello everyone - what is the process for allowing a new vault (smart contract) to lock CRV to governance?

Author: STAGHA#4583
Content: The big difference to other stablecoins is that other stablecoins are secured with tokens. There capital decides. FRAX is algorithmic. It is not capital that decides there. Their system just mints FRAX without tokens as security and pools them in the FRAX3CRV pool. As I explained, the FXS of the initial investors are bought with the CRV yields. It is effectively a closed system with the purpose of generating curve returns. I don't think it's a good look to bailout investors like Galaxy Digital. It's better to distribute to real LPs. I am only trying to enlighten one or the other CRV holder.

Author: curmudgeon#3557
Content:
There are the compound pool and the SAAVE pool. Actually, someone should propose rewriting the compound pool so that it can distribute the Compound tokens to get the extra couple % yield, but I can't see that being a higher priority until the crypto pools are industrialized.
Someone has proposed a d3pool in June (no direct expo to centralized coins like USDT or USDC) and there was a favorable snapshot vote, but this seems to have died on the vine for reasons I don't understand (I think you can search by d3pool). I would love to see that one go live with a gauge, but I wonder how much trading there would be.

If you want to be censorship resistant, you can't really rely on any centralized coin - Tether is not going to even wait for a court order if a US prosecutor asks them to freeze an address, and the onshore stablecoin providers want to effectively become the endorsed ones in lieu of a CBDC so they will probably not push back hard either.

Author: .bfs
Content:
what is the purpose of having to set a lock period when vote locking CRV? 

why not let people unlock their CRV at any time?

Author: kendrickllama
Content: whats the point of locking if you just let people unlock their crv at any time?

Author: kendrickllama
Content: thats why it's called locking

Author: .bfs
Content:
I kinda assumed that the veCRV "vesting" mechanism is what would theoretically prevent someone from wanting to unlock their CRV.

Assume a system where when 1 CRV is locked, the voting/boosting power of 1 veCRV is "vested" over 4 years, with no expiry on the lock. Someone could theoretically unlock at any time, but they would lose all the veCRV that's been vesting. 

Now obviously CRV doesn't use the above system, but I'm trying to figure out why. Is it because there would be no incentive to ever unlock CRV?

Author: curmudgeon#3557
Content: Its not vesting but escrow. You get the voting power up front for locking and it decays as you approach unlock date unless you extend. This takes crv out of circulation. It also discourages short term thinking and conflict of interest between voter and protocol. You vote for something lousy, now you've made your bed full of bedbugs and still have to sleep in it.

Author: kuhniduhni
Content:
Hey,

I have a few questions regarding Curve governance.

1) Once an on-chain vote has been created, is there a review phase before it being active? If yes, how long is it?
2) How long is an on-chain vote active? How many days?
3) Once succeeded/defeated, is there a timelock for execution/expiration? If yes, how long is it?
4) Does veCRV have to be delegated to yourself? Are there delegators?

Author: pilotvietnam
Content: No review phase once it's on chain, it's live. You can set the number of days I believe most votes go for about a week. If it passes, it's generally implemented within the week depending on the type of vote (parameter change vs something like implementation of a gauge) You can delegate your voting power through something like Convex, but individually, to vote, you would need to have locked CRV.

Content:
gauges and the veCRV whitelist are separate things
the whitelist is there to only allow regular user accounts and whitelisted contracts to lock and vote with veCRV. because otherwise it is possible to create liquid veCRV (like cvxCRV) without any of the desired effects of locking (unlike cvxCRV, cvxCRV cannot vote)

Author: orthen
Content: Hi guys, I was wondering how hard it is to get a gauge for a factory pool on a side chain. I'm aware one needs 2500veCRV to create the proposal and a 30% Quorum has to be reached. My question is, how hard is it to get the 30% quorum, anybody has some experiences/rough estimates?

Author: pilotvietnam
Content: Depends on how well the pool is seeded and that its well pegged to stand a chance of passing. Also how viable of pool it is, etc

Author: orthen
Content: What do you mean by "how viable the pool is"?

Author: orthen
Content: And if it's well seeded and nicely pegged, will it probably pass without having to bribe?

Author: wormholeoracle
Content: It generally comes down to how the asset is perceived. A protocol with a good reputation will get a gauge, a sketch one prob wonâ€™t even if you try to bribe

Author: orthen
Content: K, thank you for your answers.

Author: pilotvietnam
Content: Yeah Wormhole summed it up nicely but having a pool that is well received, seeded, and will have volume thus rewarding LP's and veCRV holders. As you can see many junk pools have been created across all chains. Many of those were not even seeded, much less doing any kind of volume.

Author: orthen
Content: Yes I see, thanks!

Author: faltino
Content:
Hi everyone,
I am Elias, currently live on Gotland a Swedish Island in the Baltic sea. Here I work in game design research at Uppsala University (they have a campus on the island)

Would love to talk to anyone that is actively involved with community building here at Curve.
I am interested in understanding the communities around governance for Curve better.

I am currently planning a qualitative study of DAOs/Blockchain project governance mechanisms and the tools and techniques they use to build communities around their values and issues of governance.  âœŒï¸

Content: I tried to post this question on suppprt channel but maybe it's more relevant for governance. I am looking at events emitted by gauge controller SC on last thursday the 24th but i don't see anything aroubd midnight

Author: pilotvietnam
Content: If you're looking for a specific contract, or have a technical question, #dev is the way.

Author: _bugfix
Content: Suppose a user votes for a pool, and then time passes and their veCRV decays to a smaller amount. They do not do any more vote transactions. Does their vote for that pool decrease? Or does the pool vote only update when they do another vote transaction?

Author: pilotvietnam
Content: Yeah weight will continue to decrease

Author: _bugfix
Content: Even if the user does not have kick() called on them? Is kick() only for boost?

Author: pilotvietnam
Content: Yes I believe just for boost. guys in #dev may be able to answer in more detail for you

Author: _bugfix
Content: It doesn't really seem like vote weight could decrease every week without more transactions, because the contract would have to update the weight for every user that voted.

Author: pilotvietnam
Content: you can verify https://dao.curve.fi/gaugeweight if you've already voted. my reflected weight is decreasing despite not having changed my vote

Author: _bugfix
Content: I don't see anywhere on that page where it says what my current weight assigned to a pool is. Only what my current weight is if I cast a new vote?

Author: _bugfix
Content: It says "You're voting with 123456.78 veCRV". But not how much veCRV is assigned to the current vote

Author: pilotvietnam
Content: I'm checking now to get clarification b/c previously, mine still shows the original weight voted with. I don't want to tell you incorrectly so standby and will update you asap

Author: pilotvietnam
Content: The dev was a little unsure as well so going up the chain just to confirm

Author: pilotvietnam
Content: Alright update from the main himself

Author: pilotvietnam
Content: https://github.com/curvefi/curve-dao-contracts/blob/master/contracts/GaugeController.vy

Author: pilotvietnam
Content: here is the contract. every users has weight but also speed of reducing their weight (bias and slope). every vote decreases linearly across their lock meaning the sume of their voting power decreases

Author: pilotvietnam
Content: code handles all that w/o checkpointing

Author: pilotvietnam
Content: TLDR yes your voting weight decreases regardless of it you checkpoint or not

Author: mimaklas
Content: 2500 veCRV at least to create a DAO vote

Author: _bugfix
Content: Thank you for taking the time to check this.

Author: _bugfix
Content: Actually I'm still not sure that GaugeController.vy handles for example multiple users all having their vote power expiring on different weeks, causing the gauge to lose total weight for each user as that happens.

Author: _bugfix
Content:
I wonder if there has been a miscommunication about our question. 
I think we both agree that vote weight for a user decreases without check points. 
But I still don't know for certain if a gauge loses weight automatically without checkpoints.

Author: _bugfix
Content:
Just to make sure I'm asking the question well, let me rephrase it:

If all the users who voted for a gauge do not ever do any transactions ever again. Does the vote for that gauge automatically decrease every week?

Content: You can track the total slope of all users, which is all you need to  decrease the total weight

Author: publius#6986
Content:
hey yall, there has not been much activity on the gauge proposal thus far. Please raise your questions and concerns, and we will try to answer them as best we can. 

Beanstalk Farms is quite excited about creating the unique yield opportunity to offer boosted CRV rewards via Convex by whitelisting cvxBEAN:3CRV for Deposit in the Silo. Having the pool added the gauge is the next step in that direction. 

Thank you for your consideration.

Author: publius#6986
Content: For reference, while the gauge proposal was originally posted a few weeks ago, Beanstalk Farms waited until the first audit of the Beanstalk code was completed to formally propose, which finally happened this week. For those of you that are interested, you can review the audit report from Omniscia here: https://omniscia.io/beanstalk-core-protocol/.

Author: The Crypto Gummy Bear#5205
Content:
I hope the Curve Communities day went well!ğŸ™‚  I wanted to send you a DM regarding giving an automated farming feature to your users for more convenience so they don't have to manually harvest their rewards. More than happy to make a proposal and put that through governance as well.
 
Instead of harvesting their rewards manually, they would be able to stake their LP, earn the rewarding token/s($CRV & $MATIC), and then sell off their earned $MATIC if its a duel rewards farm for more $CRV. Then they can have their combined rewarding token earnings of $CRV($CRV+$MATIC sold for more $CRV) staked into a single staking auto-compounding pool to earn more of that rewarding token($CRV). As an automated option, there has always been just vaults to earn more of the underlying LP. This would be earning more of the rewarding token exclusively instead of the underlying LP in an automated fashion. This would also put buy pressure on your native token $CRV. Lastly, it would also alleviate some sell pressure that Beefy puts on your token from vaulting and selling off you rewarding token for more of the underlying LP. Both of these combined will not only give users another automated option for investing, but will also potentially help the $CRV chart.

What This Means For Your Community:

-An automated farming option you can offer to your users to earn more $CRV instead of more of the underlying LP
-Buy pressure on $CRV = $CRV price rising
-Less sell pressure on $CRV because the users that prefer to earn $CRV instead of the underlying LP will now have that automated option to choose from = Also causes the price of $CRV to rise
-Another convenience option for you to offer to your users to make their lives easier for investing

Author: The Crypto Gummy Bear#5205
Content: Would love to hear your thoughts and your communities thoughts on this though. Not shilling at all. Genuinely trying to help bring investing convenience options to your community to make everyone's lives easier and help Curve. Also, do you know who the best person is I should speak with about this?

Author: The Crypto Gummy Bear#5205
Content: Would love to set up a phone call to speak more in depth on it. There are plenty of avenues that im sure we could take together depending on the goals of curve that we could help with!ğŸ˜Š

Hey guys - the StakeWise DAO has just kick-started a new curve proposal for our new liquidity pool (sETH2/stETH). Pairing StakeWiseâ€™s and Lidoâ€™s staked ETH tokens, both of which are pegged 1-to-1 with each other and ETH, allows LPs to earn staking yields on both assets within the pool. sETH2 and stETH are important assets within the ETH ecosystem and this liquidity pool will ensure efficient liquidity between staked ETH tokens as their importance grows over time.

Iâ€™m the BizDev Lead, more than happy to answer any questions regarding the above ğŸ™‚ We would greatly appreciate your support for this proposal!

I posted the XSTUSD-3CRV governance proposal on Curve forum and I am responsible for managing the process and getting us added to the Gauge controller.
I woke up to Fiddy's tweet about not trusting it and giving us a NO vote.
This is terrible, as the builders behind XSTUSD/SORA/XOR are legit (a +100 FTE fintech company celebrating 6 years, built the world's first CBDC payment system BAKONG, Polkadot core contributor since 2018, builders of Hyperledges Iroha which has been contributed to the Linux Foundation etc.).
They like to build most things in-house, just like the Oracle. It is built-in in Polkaswap DEX and uses the XOR-DAI price for XSTUSD. There are no external Oracles like Link, and the Oracle is audited and approved, nothing shady about it.

The other points Fiddy makes are mine and community members' honest mistakes.
I shared the governance post from Curve Forum with our community and a few enthusiastic members replied on it, like they do with everything we share. We were not familiar with best/common practices on Curve Forum.

About the bribes: this was also an honest mistake from my side: I did not know about the Convex Snapshot part of the voting process so I asked a community member to try https://bribe.vetoken.finance for bribing, as everything seems to be around bribing. He tested the waters with some bribes under $10k total. Then I understood how it works with Convex Snapshot, we went to sleep and woke up with Fiddyâ€™s tweet. Painful, and I feel especially bad towards the people who worked for weeks on this and trusted me with the process.

Can you and other assessment makers and strong protectors of the protocol be open for a group call or chat with our CEO/Founder of SORAMITSU? He is also the brain behind XSTUSD. https://soramitsu.co.jp 
He alsready replied to FIddy's tweet (Makoto Takemiya)

Anything we can do or elaborate on, let me know

Author: __fiddy__
Content: hey! thanks for reaching out. in general, my comments on the oracle are valid. your oracle is dependent on a singular dex, and that's a risk vector since all XOR and XSTUSD redemptions are done at that oracle price.

Author: Beno#7020
Content: Happy we are talking ğŸ™‚ Makoto (founder and brain behind XSTUSD) replied on your concerns on the governance forum:

Author: Beno#7020
Content: https://gov.curve.fi/t/proposal-to-add-xstusd-3crv-to-the-gauge-controller/2998/19

Author: Beno#7020
Content: So everyone can follow here:

Author: Beno#7020
Content:
Trading data for the Polkaswap DEX is shown here: Pairs â€?CeresToken.io

The price rate used for XSTUSD is the XOR-DAI price on Polkaswap. It is averaged over 30 blocks, with a maximum rate of change per block of 0.197% upwards and 0.007% downwards. The value of XSTUSD is guaranteed by minting XOR at the calculated XOR-DAI rate, so it will always return tokens at the value of the stable coin at the current rate, without slippage. In other words, XSTUSD is not bounded by the pool liquidity, but at least for exiting to XOR has infinite liquidity.

Because the XOR-DAI rate is internal to Polkaswap, there are no oracle operators reporting the price, as it is built into the system.

Author: Beno#7020
Content:
The auditor (Nettitude) is well-known in the enterprise space and we met them originally through our work with the Linux Foundation. The audit was done for the curve gauge proposal, about 3 months after XSTUSD went into production, so it would have been quite bad if there had been any exploits. The code itself was tested for 4 months before release, including on our public testnet.

Iâ€™m happy to share the source code or walk through it in a call if you like. We just donâ€™t want to make everything public ATM because we donâ€™t want competitors to copy all our work and also we are in the midst of refactor other parts of the system to work with our parachain (not related to XSTUSD, but we use Substrate and Substrate pallets to implement the functionality).

Just drop an email to t@soramitsu.co.jp if you want me to walk you through the source and how the stable coin works.

Author: javitoarroba#5387
Content: Hello @fiddy and all, I would like to clarify some facts that perhaps we didn't explain well. I see concerns related with the Oracle, and it's obvious, as some important hacks have exploited vulnerabilities at this point of failure regarding Oracles.  Regarding this point, Nettitude audit (pdf in the CRV proposal) is clear stating the security of the system, only recommending to audit again in the future in the case of creating new assets that by their specifications could modify the current safe status reported.  This said, the XSTUSD is not relying on real world data  averaging information from different nodes, but only relaying in the DAI price feed, so our layer of risk regarding the dolar price is directly related with the layer of risk of  DAI. It is only in the future XST synthetics to be launched, when our own Sora Oracles will become active, properly audited before.

Author: javitoarroba#5387
Content: 6s block times; but we have a max rate of change in the average per block, so it takes some time to converge to the xor-dai price if it changes dramatically; the timing was set to be reasonable if someone flash crashed the price, so that others could bring dai across the ethereum bridge to buy XOR (assuming a dramatic price decrease, it makes sense for people to arb and buy the dip, if for no other reason than arbing between exchanges, though hopefully they would also want a good deal if they knew the project fundamentals)

Author: mtakemiya#2016
Content: I should also point out, for those not familiar with the Polkadot/Kusama (DOTSAMA) ecosystem, that the SORA network is built using Parity Substrate and is using Rust compiled to WASM and not EVM/solidity. So the design of our solution is a little different than what most solidity-based projects would have.

Author: mtakemiya#2016
Content:
The price-tools (https://github.com/sora-xor/sora2-network/blob/master/pallets/price-tools/src/lib.rs) code averages over 30 blocks (with 6s blocks), but with a maximum rate of change of 0.197% per update in the average (update happens once per block) in the upwards direction, and 0.007% per update in the downwards direction. 

The price used for a USD oracle is the XOR-DAI price on https://Polkaswap.io. Because Polkaswap is an xyk constant product DEX, it is not expected to have sharp declines or surges, but rather smoother dynamics as xyk punishes price movement with a greater price impact the more you get away from the initial price point. So it is reasonable to smooth this price over time, updating the average slowly, in order to reduce the impact on short term price manipulation on the oracle price.

Hi! Was speaking with @chanho earlier who recommended I repost this in this channel. My apologies if you have already seen this message. I come to you from Aragon Network DAO!

Aragon is creating a set of 'success case' case studies of leading DAOs, and in the first set would love to cover Curve (we'll also be covering Lido and Decentraland). The case would be a short article explaining how Curve is set up today, as well as a light story of your journey to this point. The objective is to inspire new DAOs to be able to learn from Curve's experience. 

Would anyone be open to this? If so, we'd like to set up a 45 minute call with our marketing team (Lia and Harry) to interview you, and we'd send the draft of the article over to you for your review before publishing.

Author: mrsisyphos.eth
Content:
So for next epoch CRV emissions, gaugeController will take a snapshot of the veCRV for each voter at 7/7:00:00 UTC.
Let's say I started current epoch (6/30) with 100veCRV, casted a vote with 100% on 7/1 to gaugeX and end the epoch with 90veCRV on 7/7 00:00 UTC. If I got it right, my vote will count as 90veCRV for the CRV emissions of the epoch starting on 7/7. Right? (thanks for the effort of making sense of this messy question ğŸ™ )

Hey Curve DAO!

Author: m1k3#7157
Content:
Hi Curve Community! Iâ€™m Mike from the Forta Foundation.

I wanted to take a few minutes to let you know about Forta and how it can benefit the Curve community. The Forta Network is a decentralized security network monitoring blockchain activity for threats and anomalies. Think of Forta as a giant security camera and alarm system for Web 3!

Real-time monitoring is a critical pillar of any protocolâ€™s security program, and should supplement your audits and bug bounty programs. The Forta Network is currently securing over $20B of TVL across top projects like MakerDAO, Compound and Lido, and being used to early-detect exploits and other suspicious activity. 

Since Forta is a permissionless network, in some cases teams are developing and deploying their own monitoring bots directly on the network. In other cases, projects are issuing grants or bounties to their community for Forta integration.  

Hereâ€™s an example of the bots currently running on Forta (developed by community members) monitoring specific Curve activity today: https://app.forta.network/agents/curve. 

Weâ€™re interested in working more closely with your core team and community and excited to hear any feedback and questions.

Author: pilotvietnam

Author: mintmantemope
Content: this seems to be my major conclusion so far:

Author: mintmantemope
Content: Curve is one of the best examples of the intersection of DeFi and governance. Governance plays a critical role in dictating the yield of CRV holders by controlling how CRV emissions are distributed. This has spawned new protocols like Convex that manage yield optimization but require users to forfeit their governance power (remember, cvxCRV holders earn a higher yield but do not have the same governance rights as veCRV). On top of that, protocols like Votium then enable protocols to bribe users for their votes, reinforcing the role of yield as the primary driver of decision making. In short, the feedback loop between yield and governance is so directly correlated that governance on Curve is driven by yield above all else. Higher yields lead to more concentrated liquidity which leads to lower slippage â€?the major value proposition of Curve

Author: pilotvietnam
Content: i'd say maybe on protocol being whitelisted and having a majority of the voting power which we have seen, but Convex manages it well and users, with vlCVX, can vote.

Author: pilotvietnam
Content: Another is bribes. While additional rewards are great for users, it can influence more rewards being directed to gauges that don't necessarily do much volume and thus do not generate much in fees for veCRV holders

Author: mintmantemope

Author: pilotvietnam
Content: Also side note to what you said about, cvxCRV holders don't have voting power, but protocols like Stake DAO for example, allow you to vote, on gauges and proposals, along with receive rewards, and bribes with sdCRV. So works a bit differently I guess but can have many benefits. Guess the downside is they have approximately 16m CRV locked so their liquidity pool is not huge.

Author: __fiddy__
Content:
Say i am a protocol that issues stablecoins. I create an incentivised protocol owned stablecoin-eth pool and a stablecoin -3crv pool.

Arbitrage generated between dai/eth, usdc/eth and usdt/eth pools versus stablecoin/eth pool goes through the metapool.  Metapool is the ideal choice here because it guarantees deep liquidity.

That arbitrage volume generates fees for the stablecoin -3crv pool.

Author: mintmantemope
Content:
This does raise concerns over the entrenchment of governance power, particularly as it relates to the directing of CRV emissions. A protocol that accumulates significant CRV â€?they could do this through being a LP, buying CRV off secondary markets, or using other protocols like Convex â€?can more cheaply attract future liquidity because they can allocate more CRV emissions to their liquidity pools. This creates a flywheel where users are incentivized to provide liquidity to earn more CRV, which in turns increases the amount of CRV rewards the protocol earns, which then enables them to provide even more rewards to liquidity providers. Frax has pursued this strategy aggressively and now receives ~32% of all newly emitted CRV even though it only accounts for just over 1% of total volume on the Curve protocol. This raises questions over the role of governance in directing CRV emissions to the most used liquidity pools rather than the ones able to provide the highest yield. 

In 2021, a DeFi protocol Mochi attempted to implement this flywheel for their protocol. Mochi purchased ~$46 million in CVX to direct more CRV rewards to their liquidity pools and incentivize deeper liquidity. However, shortly after initiating the scheme Curve holders uncovered a number of red flags surrounding Mochi protocolâ€™s operations that prompted concerns over the allocation of so many CRV tokens to a potentially fraudulent protocol. In this case, Curveâ€™s Emergency DAO was able to respond quickly and prevent the Mochi liquidity pool from receiving CRV emissions. The event, however, created significant controversy over the power of the Emergency DAO as well as the ability of questionable protocols to easily hijack CRV emissions.

Author: el_primo9474
Content:
Dear Curve Finance team, I am Vincent, I hope you are all well. 

I am contacting you to provide our expertise in governance when it comes to the subject of DAOs. 
We are a team of academic researchers, blockchain developers, lawyers, financiers and political scientists who have been working for over 10 years to develop a scientific paradigm for collective decision making, at the intersection of social choice theory, welfare economics, decentralized artificial intelligence, collective intelligence and strategic marketing. 

We have introduced decision rules that offer expressiveness and usability, robustness in the way they analyze information, limited manipulability and scalability. 

The rules are tailor-made: governors can strategically orient the collective decision between performance, equity and consensuality.
We have solved the Condorcet Paradox: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Condorcet_paradox 
which is a 200 year old problem on governance. 

I know that there are many pain points in DAOs and the governance of blockchains protocols nowadays and there are still many challenges to overcome regarding:
- Consensus Mechanism
- Tokenization Mechanism
- Voting Mechanism
- Smart Contract Mechanism.

By working with us you will get assured to get the best recommendations/product which fit your market needs.
Do not hesitate to contact me back if this is of interests to you.

Kind Regards.


Vincent

PS: You will find in attachments a governance consulting proposal with more details regarding what we can offer.

Content: Hi. We are building a financial SAAS for DAOs and looking to offer free beta to our initial users and also get some time with the founders to get their biggest pain points and see how we can help. What would be the best way to collaborate?

Author: chanho
Content: imagine you are addressing an audience of people who have better things to do than reach out to random people in the hopes that those people have something of value to offer

Author: chanho
Content: Please explain how the Curve DAO benefits from your product and how people can check out what it does without further friction or back-and-forth or meetings.

Author: srikant#3122
Content: Yup. So we have built MVP product. Landing page for same is www.getneu.xyz. The product allows a DAO to add contributors, categorise their transactions and also see how their different wallets performed over last year/6months/1 month or week time frame.

Author: srikant#3122
Content: If possible, we want to get a small meeting scheduled with the founders so that we can see what is their biggest pain point which a SAAS company can solve.

Author: srikant#3122
Content: We have experience working at Meta, Uber, Amazon and Bloomberg.

Author: tommygenesis
Content: first sentence of the headline of your site, "We believe decentralization fairly distribute benefits to the participants" has a grammatical error

Author: chanho
Content: I find the product confusing.  You want to track member wallets performance, as though they were investments.  But your screenshots show stuff like payroll.  Seems like you are conflating various functionality into one product, trying to do everything and end up doing them poorly.  It's also unclear how you would integrate a multisig wallet into this.

Author: chanho
Content: My take is, you are still very much in the ideation stage.  Other people in the space are likely much further along.  I have heard of or seen other products that seem much more capable.

Author: srikant#3122
Content: Hi. Thank you for the feedback.  We have not added payroll yet. We provide functionality to add members/wallets/rules. We just launched MVP so yes we are pretty early. That's the reason we are looking for DAO which can play with it (for free) and provide us with valuable feedback and suggestion

Author: srikant#3122
Content: Corrected. Thank you so much for the feedback.

Content:
Hey everyone! Name's niddLer, and I'm BD for Syscoin. We are about to launch our L2 on testnet, which itself is an OP fork secured by Bitcoin's PoW.

I would love to chat with Curve team/bd team, not sure if anyone here could link me up with that, sort of a discovery call to see how we could work together!

Author: chanho
Content: I was too subtle earlier.. but I was suggesting you write up a proposal and post it here, not just repeat your brief message on doing a "discovery call".. ain't nobody got time for that here.  Could be wrong (as always).  Good luck anyway :PES_SadShrug:

Author: joaofernandess
Content:
Well, our proposal is simple:

We are launching an OP V1 fork (currently on private testnet) on an EVM that is secured by Bitcoinâ€™s PoW. We are an OG project focused on security first, convenience second and we would you guys to join our ecosystem.
Porting over will be super minimal as we are following optimismâ€™s code all the way.

Syscoin value proposition is amazing, we are actually a dual chain, with an EVM side (which is EVM compatible) and an UTXO side, which is an original bitcoin fork back from 2014. And yes, we have been around since 2014 and been developing since then.

We could easily go in depth on a call if needed!

Content:
Our TVL is not great because we haven't launched our L2. We didn't launch projects on our L1 because our L1 is not made for speed/scalability, its made for security.

We are close to launching our L2, that's why we are looking through deploying projects on there, therefore increasing our TVL.

Author: mero4336
Content:
Hi all, I try to understand the gauge weight voting  system and I have 2 questions:
1. Is there a minimum threshold to allocate the CRV to the gauge? For instance, a pool needs at least 1% of the vote to get some CRV or if a pool has 0.001% of the votes (or any %), it gets 0.001% (or any %) of the daily CRV? I know that Convex imposes a minimum of 0.1% of the vote on a pool to actually put the corresponding weight on it.
2. we can see the current and future APY, they are given in a range, what does this range mean?

Author: pilotvietnam
Content: No threshold of minimum veCRV required to vote on a gauge. If you vote on a gauge, no matter how small your veCRV and it's relative weight represents, it will be applied to the gauge you vote on and it's impact reflected the following Thursday midnight UTC. The range you're seeing is min boost ------> max boost. Your boost is deteremined by how much veCRV you have. Each gauge will differ from the next so your boost will not be the same for each gauge and will also depend on how much liquidity you have in said gauge. keep in mind also that your veCRV will boost all of your liquidity on Curve, across all gauges.

Author: mero4336
Content: I see, thank you!

Author: jam1931
Content:
Hello Curve community - Trying to do some market survey from a mature DAO like Curve (plz dont ban me ğŸ™ ). 

What do people think about a partially anonymous forum? Has anyone censored their controversial ideas due to fear of social reprisals? What have you done if your idea goes against the big players in the DAO? Can partial anonymity be a way to start addressing group think?

I understand that social reputation is important in qualifying the ideas but, it also gets in the way of viewing ideas based on its merits. In certain cases, we censor our controversial comments because it goes against the grain of the majority of DAOs and we tend to not point that out because of fear of social reprisal. Again, this may get in the way of having the most effective decision as some ideas are not considered (and that â€œconsensusâ€?is a more of a capitulation than general agreement that we have the best idea.)

I believe that certain topics may require an anon space to assess the ideas by its merits rather than rely too heavily on the social representation (albeit it has an important role in the DAO). 

How do you think anon forums would impact the quality of forum discussions?

Author: chewsizzle
Content:
Hey team, hope you guys are going well! I'm one of the partnerships managers over at CryptoTaxCalculator (https://cryptotaxcalculator.io/) and we're currently chatting to a bunch of different web3 communities to help educate them on crypto taxes (given it's such a grey area). 

We're essentially a crypto tax software for degens, crypto & nft traders and investors, been around for a few years now and we're backed by Coinbase Ventures.

We'd love to see if you guys would potentially be interested in a collaboration given the DeFi support we have on our platform. We could help educate your community in the form of an AMA or Twitter space, provide support articles on how to handle specific DeFi transactions from a tax point of view and potentially offer some sort of discount to your community. Let me know if this is of any interest and happy to chat further over a call.  ğŸ™‚

Author: jam1931
Content:
Hey Curve community - we are looking for people and DAOs to pilot test our MVP Anon forum. We want to build a decentralized and anonymous platform to facilitate meaningful and insightful discourse that further facilitates DAOs to act more effectively and efficiently. First things first, we have built an anonymous forum (via semaphore) and we are collecting people to try it out ğŸ™‚ 

We are bringing privacy to the forums because we believe anonymity can bring about change in the group think problem that DAOs are facing. Anonymity brings people down to a horizontal organization and we believe this can partly tackle the problem! We have a couple of other iterations in mind but would love some feedback! 

Please reply here or DMs are welcome too!

Author: jakesalthouse
Content:
Good evening all. I have been told to put the project I am working with here. So I am currently working with a project called Only Burns and we offer burns as a service. OnlyBurns presents; The Curve wars of Burning! Our token $OBURN is the governance token utilized within our ecosystem to vote for protocol buyback and burns of other projects. A hyper-deflationary token where holders can benefit from the deflationary aspect to obtain a larger percentage of the total supply over time. Communities from other protocols can use OBURN to vote for their project, and fight for one of the top 5 spots to earn a buyback and burn of their token! With low-supply governance boosting NFTs, power up your vote by 25%, 50%, or even 100%! 
Coming next year, $ARSON will turn up the heat! With a low supply, 500,000 tokens total, $ARSON is an actively managed ETF that gives you the ability to park your money in a positive-sum token to watch it grow in value! this is a brief description of our project and we are currently in our pre sale phase. Let me know if this community would be interested in learning more if so then maybe you can host us for a AMA (ask me anything) and you can chuck all your questions at our founder and developer. Thank you all for your time.

Author: kenshiro_28
Content: Hi! I have developed a NFT that invests all minting fees in atricrypto3 gauge on Polygon. Two-thirds of the CRV rewards earned on the atricrypto3 gauge are used to buy MANA (Decentraland) and deposit it in the rewards fund. The remaining third of the rewards are reinvested in the atricrypto3 gauge, increasing performance over time.

Author: kenshiro_28
Content: You earn passive income just by holding NFTs in your wallet

Author: kenshiro_28
Content: it's already working, minting fees are only 0.1 DAI and max supply is 1 billion

Author: kenshiro_28
Content: I would like this belongs to the Curve project, the more people use it, the best for everyone as each individual harvest triggers automatic compounds in the shared fund.

Author: kenshiro_28
Content: Of course the NFT has no owner privileges and I didn't pre-minted NFTs for me.

Author: kenshiro_28
Content: Is there any chance devs will check it? ğŸ™‚

Author: chanho
Content: why is it an NFT rather an ERC20?

Author: kenshiro_28
Content: people like NFTs and this one is very affordable so this would be widely distributed. When max supply is reached they will start to increase value in the market, according to the rewards per NFT. It's also a simple way of earning passive income, just holding in the wallet. Staking is not required. It also allows additional functionality. New farms and services could be created that recognize the NFT as a deposit.

Author: kenshiro_28
Content: the max number of users is the number of NFTs which should push up the value in the long term. You are right in that this could be done also with an ERC20 token without decimals, but it's more cool with NFTs and has a nice picture of a dragon although is the same in all. This is more about passive income that having different art in each NFT.

Author: kenshiro_28
Content: note that each NFT has a unique id, so future services could register stats of a particular NFT.

Author: chanho
Content: hm, interesting idea, not convinced but often i'm overly skeptical about these things

Author: chanho
Content: what kind of stats do you think would be interesting to people?

Author: chanho
Content: it would be fun if different designs were related to different yields

Author: kenshiro_28
Content: you could have stats on a future game, like player location, life, abilities ...

Author: kenshiro_28
Content: any service that requires each user has different attributes

Author: kenshiro_28
Content: what I would like most is passive "multifarming"

Author: kenshiro_28
Content: the same NFT earns yield from an increasing number of farms which recognize it as a deposit, just by holding in the wallet.

Author: kenshiro_28
Content: the team could use funds in the treasury to create these farms

Author: kenshiro_28
Content: anyone could do it

Author: kenshiro_28
Content: for example, if I want to promote my new project, I create a farm with my own token that recognizes the NFT as a deposit

Author: kenshiro_28
Content: then I come here or do marketing to inform NFT holders that they can also harvest from this new project. And users don't have to do anything, just click on harvest when they want.

Author: Oliver | Phuture#0686
Content:
We have put a proposal up on the gov forum to bring USV, the first USDC bond ETF to curve. Bringing an asset that generates 3%+ in yield and pairing it with fraxbp for additional incentives. USV is redeemable for USDC at anytime and trades in a very tight range. 

This is our first exchange listing for USV so Curve will be the only destination to trade it right now. Our aim is to increase tvl and holders for USV whilst simultaneously contributing to the liquidity of FRAXBP and the curve ecosystem. 

https://gov.curve.fi/t/proposal-to-add-usv-fraxbp-to-the-gauge-controller/8687

Author: Bruce#6146
Content:
sure, so we`ve integrated Curve DEX into EtherDrops. 

Users are now able to receive notifications relating to swaps on various chains and price changes. Those notifications are customised based on user settings. For example, notify me if there is a swap greater than $xxx between XYZ and other token etc. 

The following makes activity & transactions monitoring easy, which brings a lot of value to the community, That`s why EtherDrops is so popular. 

Would you be interested to announce this integration/retweet our Tweet? It is already up and running, so no help needed from your side relating to tech/support side.

Author: secondsetmaze
Content:
I enjoyed reading this. Creative use of the gauge infrastructure for those projects that are ineligible due to Grant Council guidelines... and also a possible way for veCRV voters to "get in early."

You said it best at the end, however... It's up to the new protocol to convince voters to support this cause when the token being bribed is neither immediately promising nor liquid. 

I am hoping that the Llama Risk team will weigh in and educate veCRV voters with findings and reports during the stages of Governance Proposal, Deploy, and Vote.

The Paladin team is friendly and welcoming. I would like to see @Beguin, who is the gigabrain behind Paladin's Weekly Gauge Newsletter (a SUPER read each week) collaborate on marketing of this concept. In addition to the curve and convex places suggested to market their plan, new projects looking to raise funds this way might be the subject of a "Weekly Gauge" article and respond to questions from Beguin. 

Finally, Happy Anniversary to veFunder ! 
Thanks, Wormhole
